Roseau River Indian Day School

Please find attached your security deposit cheque in the amount of $....... forwarded here in connection with advertising for tenders for the erection of the above school.

CONTRACT AGREEMENT

THIS AGREEMENT made (in triplicate) the seventh day of October in the year nineteen hundred and sixty-five A.D.

BETWEEN

North American Lumber and Supply Company, Winnipeg, Manitoba,

hereinafter called "The Contractor", of the first part;

AND His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, hereinafter called "The Minister", of the second part,

WHEREAS the party of the first part, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the party of the second part, to do, furnish and perform the work, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in the manner hereafter described, in connection with the work or works;

NOW THIS INDENTURE IT ESSETH that the said parties hereto, hereby covenant, promise and agree, each with the other as follows:

ARTICLE I: The covenants, clauses, provisos and conditions of the Tender Form, General Instructions to Bidders, and Specifications, (embracing the General Conditions, Labour Conditions, General Specifications and Trade Specifications) together with the drawings and such additional detail drawings, shop drawings and instructions, as may from time to time be furnished, shall be as fully part of this Agreement as if attached hereto, or herein repeated, and should the Contractor or Minister fail to sign them, they shall nevertheless be binding on both parties.

-1-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6250, file 560-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
ARTICLE II: The Contractor undertakes and agrees:

(a) to do, furnish and perform, the works, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in connection with the following work or works namely,

The erection of a one-room school and attached teacher's residence in accordance with drawings and specifications of Plan 689, Department of Mines and Resources. This school to be located at a site on the South Red Indian reserve to be indicated by the Indian Superintendent, Portage la Prairie Agency. This building must be built with a foundation one foot higher than that shown on the drawings.

(b) to complete substantially, and to the satisfaction of the Minister, all the work, on or before the date or dates following, viz:

the...fifteenth............. day of December...........

Nineteen Hundred and Forty-Nine................A.D.

(c) Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

ARTICLE III: The Minister undertakes and agrees, in consideration of the premises, and subject to the performance and observation on the part of the Contractor, of all covenants, provisos and conditions in the specifications contained:
(a) To pay the Contractor in current funds, for the performance of the contract .................. Eleven Thousand Two Hundred Dollars ($11,200.00) ................ subject to additions and deductions as provided for in the Specifications governing the work.

(b) To make progress payments on account thereof, as provided for in the Specifications, equal to ninety per cent (90%) of the value, proportionate to the amount of the Contract, of labour and materials incorporated into the work, as estimated by the Engineer, less the aggregate of previous payments.

(c) On completion of the entire work, and on full performance of the covenants and clauses of the Specifications, to make full payment of the balance due under the Contract, as set out in the Specifications.

ARTICLE IV: The Contractor and the Minister for themselves, their successors, executors, administrators and assigns, hereby undertake and agree, to the full performance of the covenants contained herein.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF these presents have been signed and sealed on behalf of His Majesty, by the Deputy Minister of the Department of Mines and Resources, and the Contractor, the day and year first above written.

My Lord Archbishop,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Grace's letter of the 14th instant, and regret to find that Your Grace is not satisfied with the grounds upon which the Department bases its inability to give assistance towards re-opening a school at Gambler's Reserve, and should feel compelled to still insist upon such being done.

It is hoped that the following fuller explanation of the Department's policy will convince Your Grace of the impossibility of consistently meeting Your Grace's wishes in this direction, much as it always desires to do so when it can.

The Department's policy has been to provide as far as possible Industrial and Boarding Schools, not alone on account of their superior advantages as compared with Day Schools, from which experience has proved that little benefit is derived, but also to enable children to be removed to a distance from contact with the objectionable influences of the Reserves, and consequently brought more fully under that of their preceptors. When these Industrial and Boarding Schools were established it was with the understanding that they would

His Grace
The Archbishop of St. Boniface,
St. Boniface,
Manitoba.
would, to a considerable extent, enable the Department to dispense with Day Schools on the Reserves, which, as already said, have been found to be of little benefit, and indeed it is only the greatest retrenchment with regard to the latter class that at all justifies the cost of maintaining the former, or enables it to be met.

It may be observed in passing that in pursuance of this policy in the District to which Your Grace makes reference Day Schools have been dispensed with at the Crooked Lakes and Muscowpetung Agencies respectively, and at the latter, and largely with a view to enforcing cultivation of the Industrial School at Regina, the Boarding School at Lakes End, one of those mentioned by Your Grace, has recently been closed. In this connection it may be mentioned that another of the schools referred to by Your Grace, namely, a Day School at Turtle Mountain, although countenanced by the Department, has received no grant from it.

There are of course Reserves where circumstances require Day Schools still to be maintained, but wherever the number of children and other circumstances are such as to make it possible to provide for the children by sending them to Industrial or Boarding Schools, (and the Department considers that Gambler's Reserve belongs to this class,) it is felt that such should be done, and until children from such Reserves have been accommodated those at Reserves where there are Day Schools made to attend them.

Experience
Experience has proved that exercise of energy and persistence does succeed in getting parents to send children to a greater distance than separates Gambler's Reserve from Qu'Appelle, and it is hoped Your Grace will recognize that the superior advantages more than compensate for any inconvenience which the parents complain of, and that they should be encouraged to send their children to Qu'Appelle as vacancies occur.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of May 31st last No. 111587 regarding the request of the Chief and Councilors of the Waywayseecappo's reserve No. 62 for the purpose of opening a day school on the reserve I wish to report as follows:

The families on the reserve are scattered all over the reserve and their houses are quite a distance apart. This would entail, if a day school was opened, the necessity for vans to be in operation to take the children to the school. The expenses would be large and the attendance, in my opinion, would not be satisfactory unless compulsory attendance was strictly enforced.

The object of the Indians in wanting a day school opened on the reserve is to keep them from sending their children to the Boarding schools; this applies especially to the parents who are Roman Catholics who are adverse to sending their children on account of the long distances of their schools from their reserve.

DR. MCGILL:

I am submitting herewith, for your consideration, a request for the establishment of an Indian day school on the Waywayseecappo reserve, received by the Department from Reverend Father J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

In this letter Dr. Allen, on behalf of the Synod, protests very vigorously against the establishment of a Catholic Church or an Indian day school on the Waywayseecappo reserve.

Despite this fact, however, the agent declares that the children are recognized as Catholics.

In view of the opposition that is likely to develop, should an attempt be made to build an Indian day school on this reserve, I suggest that this correspondence, together with any recommendation you may care to make, be submitted to the Minister for his consideration.

I have heard that at some of the Western Reserves there is a farm instructor engaged by the Government for boys of a certain age but do not know just how much is included in this kind of instruction.

The above parties state that there are about fifty children on the Rolling River Reserve, and thirty on the Reserve at Elphinstone, and that the number at Rossburn would be approximately one hundred. This, no doubt, includes the children of all ages from seven up to eighteen or nineteen.

The said Councillors state that at all of the meetings held on the three reserves, the Indians expressed the desire to have day schools established on each Reserve so that, if possible, the children might stay at home and be under their parents supervision during the school period. As you no doubt know, the Indians are very fond of their children and, like other parents, wish to have them at home as much as possible during their school years.

The Councillors have the idea that the Queen told the Indian people in the treaties made many years ago that they would have the right to have their children educated on the Reserves. I do not know what the treaties may have provided in this respect but the Indians seem to attach great importance to the alleged promise.

I mentioned to the Councillors the matter of the large investment in the Birtle Indian School, also the considerable further expenditure which would be necessitated by establishing schools on the Reserves. They do not appear to have considered this angle of the matter very much but I think they appreciate the difficulty from the financial standpoint. They, however, are very anxious to have the separate schools established on the Reserves if that is at all possible and have instructed me to write your Department to ascertain what you would be prepared to do along that line. If it should be found impracticable to grant their request at the present time they are strongly in favor of adding instruction in practical farming and suitable vocational training to the curriculum at the Birtle School.

Although the Councillors did not mention this possibility, it occurs to me that the ideal solution

of this problem would be to establish day schools upon the Reserves for the younger children between the ages of seven and thirteen and to make vocational training available for the children from thirteen and upwards. Dear Sir,

Pursuant to the promise I made to you when Professor Hart and I talked with you during your recent visit to Winnipeg, I now write about the matters of our interview. After several postponements we have had an interview on these subjects with the Commissioner and have laid before him our wishes with respect to them.

1. In the matter of the additional land for the Reserve of the Sioux Indians near Prince Albert I need say nothing further since there has already been correspondence on that subject.

2. We are anxious that the Government should undertake the erection of an addition to the Birtle Indian Boarding School. This school was established by the Presbyterian Church, with the approbation of the Government, in 1888. Birtle is an extremely central and convenient point for such an institution, for there are Reserves on almost all sides of it. The school has been very successful and has now an average attendance of about forty-five pupils. The reports of the local Agent and of the Inspectors have been uniformly of a very favorable character. The Presbyterian Church owns thirty acres of land in connection with the school,
and buildings to the value of about $7,000., the mission building being a substantial and well built stone structure which now serves as school-room, residence for the pupils and residence for the staff. The land was purchased and the buildings erected entirely at the cost of the Presbyterian Church. If the Government agrees to erect an additional building for the accommodation of the school, and is unwilling to build it upon land which is not its property, we would be quite willing to deed a suitable site to the Government; or if it is thought advisable, a convenient site can be purchased from another proprietor within a few yards of the present building. The reasons upon which we base our request to the Government for the erection of an additional building or the enlargement of the present building are mainly these -

(1) The school is centrally situated, is largely patronized and is doing excellent work; the present accommodation is entirely too small and there is urgent need for an enlargement.

(2) Before the present building was erected and while the school was being carried on in rented premises, the Honorable E. Dewdney, then Superintendent of Indian Affairs and Minister of the Interior, promised inviting that the Government would bear the cost of such buildings as were needed. Very much to his own regret, his fellow members of the Council failed to grant the money required; but I quote this to show that the school is one which has long enjoyed the good will of the Department, and the Church did not undertake the erection of the buildings until there was an urgent demand for them.

(3) The additional accommodation for which we ask has already been asked for by the local Agent.
(4) The accompanying statement showing the amounts paid towards the erection of boarding schools in Manitoba and the North West indicates that during recent years the Presbyterian Church, although it has made repeated requests, has not been receiving a large share of Government patronage.

3. The Presbyterian Church wishes to undertake a mission on the West side of the Lake of the Woods. About this we believe the Rev Dr Moore of Ottawa, Convener of the Missionary Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, and the Rev Principal Grant have already interviewed the Minister of the Interior. There is a considerable number of Indians numbering between 550 and 600, in the neighborhood of the North West angle and Shoal Lake for whom nothing at all of a missionary or educational character is being done. It is true that Priests of the Roman Catholic Church have, at infrequent intervals, paid them visits, usually when they were gathered together at the time of treaty payments; but there has been no steady and persistent effort to reach them with the benefits of education and of the Gospel. The Church of England, which has several missions on the other side of the Lake of the Woods, has through the Venerable Archdeacon Phair, Superintendent of Indian Missions, expressed hearty approval of our proposal to do something for these people. The Indians themselves of two of the Shoal Lake bands have sent a formal request, asking us to establish a school at some central place for the benefit of their children.

The Secretary:

In reference to the letter of the 7th instant from the Rev. D. Baird, Joint Convener of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, Winnipeg, applying, inter alia, for the erection of an addition to the Birtle Boarding school, I beg to say that the records of this Department bear out the reverend gentleman's assertion as to the success of this school, provision for which is now made at the rate of $12 per capita for 40 pupils.

The Indians in the vicinity of the school have frequently objected to having their children sent to any great distance from their Reserves and have expressed their preference for the Birtle school.

The Industrial school at Regina, which is conducted under auspices of the Presbyterian Church, has an enrollment of 131 with provision for 140 at $130 per capita, being a difference of $58 in the cost per head of the two schools.

I consider that a boarding school, for all practical purposes achieves equally good work with an Industrial school with pupils up to a certain age—say about 14 years—and at a much less cost. If the Department considers it advisable to increase the grant to any of the denominations now carrying on Indian schools, I should say that the money could be spent to much better advantage in
in assisting or establishing boarding schools, than increasing the number of Industrial schools, or making provision for more pupils at those already established.

Dr. Baird also asks for the erection of a building suitable for a boarding school, at or near Keewatin or some other suitable place in the neighborhood of the North-West Angle and Shoal Lake and a per capita grant of $72 for such children as may be gathered into the school.

Dr. Baird states that the Church of England, which has several missions on the Lake of the Woods, has, through the Ven. Archdeacon Phair, Supt. of Indian missions, expressed hearty approval of the proposal of the Presbyterian Church to do something for these people, and the Indians themselves have sent a formal request asking for the establishment of a school for the benefit of their children.

The Census Return for 1897 shows most of the Indians in this locality as pagans, while a number of Bands north of Lake of the Woods are put down as Anglicans and Roman Catholics.

A boarding school was recently established at Rat Portage under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, to which the Department contributed $2500 and provided for 20 pupils at $72 per capita.

Sir,

I have the honour to report for your information that yesterday evening the 12th instant a fire took place in the basement of the Birtle Boarding School and damage to the amount of $75.00 or $100.00 done. The fire was caused by the furnace pipe getting hot and setting fire to the joist in the first floor which runs quite close to the pipe. This joist was burnt about ten feet and laths on part of the partitions first floor scorched. Most of the damage to the building was caused by our having to break down the partitions and flooring to locate the fire and keep it from spreading. The fire started about 10:30 p.m. and was first noticed by Mr. Small, the Principal, who was returning from town. The alarm was given to the town people through the Matron and assistants shouting fire.

I was amazed on arriving at the school to see what a fire-trap the work about the furnace pipe hole was, the laths running almost up to the pipe and it is a mystery that the building has escaped so long. The builder deserves censure, for had the fire occurred later many lives would have been lost. Most of the plaster in the clothing-room was broken down, also part of the flooring and part of the plaster

It was caused by the wood-work catching fire from the furnace pipe, running through the new wing, in the school-room floor. I examined the pipe hole where the fire started, and was surprised at the poor work done around the thimble running through the floor, in fact it was a veritable fire-trap. Both samples contain organic matter in suspension and solution but the samples are too small to permit of its determination as to quantity or character. Instead of 1 quart, at least 2 or 3 quarts should be furnished.

Dear Mr. Pedley:

I feel some hesitation in returning with another request so soon after the kindness of the Department in raising the per capita at the Portage School from 25 to 30. Yet I take the liberty of presenting another similar case, equally encouraging and deserving. Our Board during the last year expended in the Birtle Boarding School $6080.00, not only putting the school in a state of repair but purchasing a large tract of land,-240 acres in all. The building as formerly arranged would accommodate 50 pupils, but will now accommodate ten more,-60 in all. The present enrollment is 53. The Indians on the neighboring Reserve are unusually friendly, as is the case on all the Reserves recently. Without solicitation eight boys and two girls have come from the Lizard Point Reserve and more are promised for 1909. This is of course encouraging to the Department as it is to us, and especially to the missionaries. We have in Mr. McLaren far and away the most aggressive men we have yet employed. He is so strong a man intellectually and scholastically that it is only the question of health that has led him into the Indian service. Now that we have him we must try and keep him.

In order to make it possible to take in as many children as there is accommodation for, would it be possible to increase their per capita grant for 1909? If so it will be much appreciated.

Dear Sir,

Your favor No. 16624/1 of the 16th inst. came duly to hand.

I desire to bring to your attention the policy of your Department as to the desirability of providing a competent practical farming instructor for the crops of this school. At the time I came to the school five years ago, I felt that something more than was being done should be done in the way of keeping the crops occupied and producing them for future use on the farm. We had then but two acres in crop. During the next two years we broke up all the arable land on their head - some thirty acres in all. By examining closely one of the new reserves, the church authorities gave me a grant of $250 per year towards the salary of a farm instructor. With that, they managed to have a new house built, provided a land locker of farming experience in the Old Country for the first part of each year, but now that we have some acres in crop this year and will have about 120 acres in subsequent years, and now that we have a large number of boys over fifteen years of age, I feel with you something more permanent and effective is needed. Up until now, any money I could spare has been devoted to the equipment of the farm. In fact, the last two years, I have spent some $100 in the last two years. Unfortunately, this hail and frost during the last few years, particularly the last three, saw some loss and beef cattle. We have had no revenue from the farm and have had to expend from $250 to $300 a year for fodder and seed. Last year we got with 175 bushels from 50 acres of crop because of hail. The result is a deficit of some $150 against the school due almost entirely to the loss by hail and frost in our farming operations. This rather discouraging state of affairs also militates against any larger outlay towards the salary of a first class farm instructor. I trust that with the closing of spring, our school may have an opportunity of completing its equipment from the funds saved by stock and implements necessary to work the large farms, anticipating somewhat your suggestions and in view of the necessity of having a competent man to take my place while I should be absent or otherwise engaged.

I have signed J. H. McLean, B.A., M.B., B.S., as farm instructor and assistant principal. Mr. Snyder is a new teacher by both and having spent fifteen years on a farm there. He is a productive A.

Dear Sir,

In order to expedite the work of the Battle Indian School after my return on October 1st, I would like to bring the following matters before the attention of the Department so that their reply will await my arrival in Battle.

I would apply for leave of absence for oldest pupil, Miss Swetlale Blackbird, so that she may go to Toronto in October to attend the Everett Training Home in connection with the Presbyterian Church in Canada - with a view to getting training in nursing and house hold service with a view to becoming qualified to assist a nation or nurse in our school or hospital. While in Edinburgh, demand the allotment of trust funds to the extent of $100 per year for the education of our graduates who by the proper qualifications mind and character do work of an educational or missionary nature among their own people. Miss Blackbird is the first to benefit under the fund. Only Indian boys and girls of very superior character will be recommended in the future and all subsequent graduates drawn and from the fund must express their willingness to pursue their further education under the immediate supervision of one of our Boarding Schools or of one of our church mission or colleges such as the one at Red River. Miss Blackbird is 15yo. and also to devote themselves to work among their own people subsequent to graduation under some Protestant body interested in Indian work. I have another boy recently from Regina - Alice Field by name who is attending the Battle Public School with a view to becoming a teacher. If he succeeds in securing a certificate and proves himself worthy, this same fund will provide for his professional training at the Normal School at Portage la Prairie. In this way there will be a minimum risk of our graduates becoming separated from their own race and from work among and for them.

I should like the Department to consider the admirable manner in which Miss Blackbird has conducted the hospital during the last four months. It is reported that she has taken full charge of the patients, discharged her duties with great satisfaction to herself, and has been able to perform them during my frequent visits. She has effected a saving of the usual salary paid to a trained nurse of $5 per month for four months or $20 in all. I would suggest that an allowance be made for her work and that an increase be given her training this winter, she be granted $15 per month or $60 in all. The school gave her $20 per month last winter when acting as substitute for Miss Macgregor in the classroom.

Lastly, I should like to know what steps have been taken in connection with the tent hospital associated with the Bertha School. Prior to its removal to Bertha, I agreed to become responsible for its financial management and for its general supervision under the direction of Mr. Agent Wheatley and to finance it for the year at a maximum outlay of $250 spent from the reserve of removing the tents from Wagway to Bertha and of rebuilding them there. I have not the exact figures at my hand but so I recollect them, the gross cost of maintenance was including considerable capital expenditure for a new tent and furniture and clinical supplies has been considerably under $250 for 14 months. The hospital has done good work, has won the confidence of the Indians, and the wagway occupiers, and has given our older pupils good training in simple nursing. I am quite ready to continue to do what I agreed to a year ago, but if the hospital is to be habitable for the winter certain improvements will have to be made immediately. The two tents used by the patients as sick wards are no longer satisfactory. The strain of the weather during four years constant service has worn out the cotton that they no longer afford protection to those sheltered within. We found also that a tent was hardly suitable as a constant abode for the nurses, and it would be difficult to get a good nurse.
I have been consulting with those connected with tuberculosis institutions in Great Britain and Canada during my absence and also attended the Tubercular Congress in Edinburgh last June and practically all are opposed to the use of the tent for hospital purposes save an open outdoor shelter from wind and rainstorms saying they are difficult to ventilate and also that they also provide no dormitories. One of the chief requisites along with fresh air and food is clean water. In our region where they are also less available in temperature and too expensive in the matter of fuel. If the Department deemed it advisable to continue the hospital upon the tent a permanent building basis, I would advise the erection of simple inexpensive wooden structures of the same size as the tents above mentioned providing a maximum of sunlight and fresh air. Beyond the framing of the structure practically all the normal labor will be done by the older boys once proficient in wood working and carpentry at Regina. The total cost would be little more than that necessary to replace the tents; the outlay would be fixed and the structure could be constructed to admit of being easily taken down in case a removal was deemed advisable future time. If it is decided to go on as before with the abro improvements included, I shall then be in a position to provide for the necessities of the winter in the way of fuel, drug and food supplies—things which would not come under pending definite instructions.

I would advise also the insurance of the tents and other property of the hospital—the cost to be met out of the vote for maintenance. The whole property especially if improved otherwise will be worth from $100 to $200 and when so many storms and such a precaution against loss would limit the responsibility of them in case of the hospital.

Finally, I shall be endeavoring to secure a successor for Mr. Blackbird and I should like to receive your advice whether the instructions of the Department in that connection.
I regret that owing to my lack of foresight in arranging for my return passage from Liverpool to the West, I did not secure tickets permitting my going to Ottawa and returning in person the matter referred to in this form. I trust that even more than in the past, the work done in the future may merit the confidence and commendation of the Department.

Kindly address reply to me at the Butte School.

Dear Sir,

As convenor of the Committee in charge of Indian missions within the Province of Manitoba and the North Agency I was directed to send a confidential statement as to the condition of the work on the various reserves, and in the school, suggesting certain things which in our opinion would lead to more efficient results.

We would endorse heartily the action of the Department in appointing a special officer to enforce the Indian Act, while we feel a short-service official whose identity would be absolutely unknown to Indians outside settlers would secure a more thorough enforcement of the law especially against the hardened offenders most of whom so far have managed to avoid capture; and also a more equitable distribution of sentences (many of the officials would have no political business or social affiliations) yet while knowing the personal weaknesses in character of some respects in the Indians we feel he is the most competent official to secure for himself in this agency there has been less drinking, less wandering about, and more attention to farm work during this last summer than in many a previous year. The large amount of breaking occurring following these promises will for another year. The continuance of the special officer for another year would conserve the gains already made.

We would ask that all offenders be prosecuted without fear of favor outside settlers whether they wish it or not be admonished or give evidence. Cases particularly at Waywayseecappo and Keewatinwinni were not prosecuted because of the aloofness of certain settlers. Certain old offenders escaped because of their deceiving information against them. Offenders with less social influence are punished and some were let off lightly or not punished.

because of family and other affiliations, while depreciating the infliction of severe penalties on the Indians—still we think something more than a mere talking to or empty threats is required to instill respect for the law. Dear Sir,

I would notify you of joint action taken after consultation with Dr. Scott Whalley and Dr. F. O. Gilbert our medical officer in cooperation with Charles J. Andrews, Pupil No. 320. This boy had his left eye ball burst while watching an older boy lift a pair of tongs out of an old crockery pan - by means of a looped piece of wire. The weight of the water in the pan caused the small end of the loop to spring back and strike the boy's eye with force enough to rupture it. Fearful of the injured eye by the injury and of the healthy eye in case sympathetic inflammation set in, I had the midnight surgeon stop his Sabbath evening - a few hours after the accident and took the boy to St. Boniface Hospital for treatment by Dr. Ford. Within half an hour after our arrival the eye was examined by Dr. Tremblay, Dr. Ford's partner. He is fearful not only of the sight being lost in the eye but also that it may have to be removed to prevent injury to the other. Meanwhile he is doing his best to save the injured eye by prompt disinfecting the boy for life. We believe will report more fully in connection with his monthly hospital report.

I trust this best but necessary procedure will meet with your approval.

Yours sincerely,

W. M. Harris
Principal.

Dear Sir,

You have in No. 624/11 of the 17th inst., regarding the purchase of supplies for the Billie Indian School and its provisions in particular, come duly before me in reply I would give the main principles governing me in my purchases both for the school and for the Indian Hospital.

Firstly, I consider the money placed in my hands as a trust committed to me by the Indian Department and by the Presbyterian Church in Canada. As such, it is my duty to expend them to the best advantage, irrespective of any affiliations political, ecclesiastical or geographical. This trust is now incumbent upon me among this school has been, and so today laboring under a heavy deficit incurred almost wholly in an endeavor to provide the pupils with the most wholesome diet possible and to provide our farm with a proper equipment. By during the last seven years - the same standard of expenditure for foodstuffs had prevailed in Billie School as has prevailed in even our other Presbyterian Schools - we would have had no deficit but owing to the presence of a very large proportion of children in this agency predisposed to scurvy, pulmonary tuberculosis and anaemia complicated with heart weakness and owing to the complaints made by the Indians particularly in the earlier years of my principalship as to the quality, variety, and quantities of food given the children and owing to reports asked for from me as house diet by the Department itself - our expenditure for foodstuffs was raised from 27¢ per capita in 1905 to 38¢ per capita in 1911. The difference in these rates will represent the actual increase because the purchase of provisions from wholesale establishments has never been considered balanced therein in the cost of foodstuffs. The purchase of provisions locally meant either a larger deficit for the school to carry or a decrease in the quantity of food or the purchased a poorer quality. Our local merchants had full control over supplies until 1904. They looked upon the schools legitimate pay for private gain upon a retail basis and not as institution doing a work of charity and purchasing food upon a wholesale basis. The class-room was visited and was clean and in good order. The pupils present were clean and fairly well clothed. Progress noted in the girls in the different grades, in reading, writing and arithmetic. The boys are making no progress at all, and the lack of discipline amongst them is very marked. They pay very little heed to their teacher, and this is very noticeable amongst the bigger boys, who think that they are too big to go to school. Calisthenics are taught daily, but the boys take no interest in this and the performance I saw must be very discouraging to the teacher. There seems to be a lack of union and harmony between the principal and the ladies of the staff, and this may account for the lack of discipline amongst the boys, as they are very quick to notice, and this seeming lack of harmony is doing lasting harm to the school.

As this school is rated No.1, and receives a Government grant of $125.00 per capita for 50 pupils, the staff should be increased, so as to give the best instruction and care to the pupils. A male teacher should be employed to take charge of the boys, one who had a knowledge of drill, and would be a strict disciplinarian. We also put before them the several reasons why every parent who has children of school age, should send all who were physically fit to attend. The Indians on each reserve gave us a hearty welcome and all expressed their views, that it was a good thing to have their children educated. As conditions in the school had not been as they should have been, owing to lack of discipline, and the proper teaching of English, through the pupils having been allowed to speak their own language most of the time. They also felt that something was radically wrong to account for the frequent runaway of the pupils. The Indians found fault with the school on these heads. It was explained to them that these matters would be remedied, and the Department would now have a closer supervision over the school, and that the new Principal had the authority to discharge any member of the staff.

Ottawa, September 22, 1914.

Sir,

In reply to the inquiries contained in your letter or the 9th instant I beg to say that this Department has supervision and control of the residential Indian schools and it does not sanction the admission of Roman Catholic children to Protestant schools and vice versa. It is the duty of Indian Agents to see that this rule is carried out. The clergy have no authority to take a child without the consent of the parent or guardian. Neglected children can be committed to industrial or boarding schools under the Regulations passed by authority afforded by sections 9, 10 and 11 of the Indian Act, chapter 61 of the Revised Statutes of Canada. The Portage la Prairie Boarding School is conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church, but all Protestant schools are open to Protestant children, if there are vacancies.

Miss Elizabeth McCurdy, the teacher has had four years' experience in the Indian work. Dear Sir,

Your letters of 18th ult. and 22nd ult. have come duly to hand.

Regarding the heating plant, I beg to state that the plant was examined last winter by a skilled workman and pronounced in good condition. The small repairs that are now necessary can easily be done before the plant is needed. I would point out, however, that the real difficulty with the plant is due to the long distance the steam has to go in making its circuit. The far end of the class room is over 70 feet away from the boilers and it takes a very high pressure to keep up steam with such a length of pipe and radiators. This difficulty can only be overcome by constant attention and an abundant supply of fuel. It is too late now to discuss alterations in the plant. No matter what the Government inspectors may ask, I would not recommend touching the plant. I think, however, that a better stove in the class room would be all right. There should also be a better stove in the laundry as the old stove there now is wasting fuel.

Regarding the water supply, I have already informed the Department that our present supply is insufficient, and that I would not approve the sinking of a well at the back of the school as there is no likelihood of our obtaining a permanent supply.
from that source. The Government has already refused to repair their own well that caved in through bad workmanship. I don't see why we should do it when we have water enough without.

I think we can get the old poultry house repaired at a small cost, and we have part of the work done. This building was out of use for some years. We need a good place for pigs if we are to continue to keep them.

Regarding the report of Inspector Jackson regarding moral conditions here, I would beg to point out that the matters dealt with in his so-called investigation were fully considered by Dr. Murray on his visit here last winter. The main point was that two girls, pupils of the school, gave birth to children. Both these girls had been absent during the month of July for holidays. Both laid the blame on pupils of the school. I accepted the statement of the first as true and was a consenting party to a marriage between the persons named. I have since had strong suspicions that I was deceived, but cannot say for certain as the child was of premature birth. In the second case I was positive that the girl had been guilty of immorality on the reserve during holidays and that it was impossible that the boy named should be guilty, as he was at school and they could not have met for over two months. The birth of the child showed that I was right, but the parents of the girl were angry that their plans miscarried and I have since been informed they have slandered myself in connection with the matter, but not before the Inspector.

The problem of safeguarding the girls both in and out of school is always a difficult one in Indian schools, more especially
as little or no dependance can be put in the girls themselves, and here where there is so much cover the problem is more difficult. After thinking the matter over I determined to make the work of supervision easier for the matrons by enclosing the girls playground with a strong fence. This was completed in August last and since then we have had no trouble with girls straying beyond bounds. I cannot however say that there will be no trouble of the same kind as last year, as I do not think the parents will take the trouble to look after the girls properly during holidays.

Now, regarding the fact of my residence being a mile away, I think my wife has more reason to complain than either the Church or the Government. Mr. Jackson made a note of the fact that I am here almost the whole time from the time the children get up in the morning until they go to bed at night and the farmer is just as constantly on duty and very seldom away at night or in the evenings. His room is at the foot of the stairs where the boys come down. I have no reason to believe that the big boys come down the stairs at night and Mr. Jackson can produce no evidence to that effect. It is only a simple matter to turn a key to lock them in, but we have no done so regularly, as I did not think it necessary, and I am still of the same opinion. I have already pointed out to you the advantage of having a good handy reliable man about the school all the time, but this would not be advisable unless the attendance is larger. So far as I can see the discipline of the school has been steadily improving and the supervision of the children has been as close as at any period in the history of the school. Truancy has now almost disappeared.
In regard to Miss McCurdy, I have given the matter careful attention and regret to state that so far as I can see the only satisfactory course is to remove her from here and appoint a new teacher in her place. I thought that I had made that plain to you a year ago. My letter in the winter had reference solely to the threatened action against her for slander. I did not intend it to be taken as an endorsement of her work. I have never been satisfied with the results of her teaching larger pupils and do not think results from her teaching ever will be satisfactory.

If it is possible to secure a good male teacher I think that would be the easiest way of meeting the wishes of the Department. If that is not possible a good strong woman would do. It will also be necessary to secure another assistant matron for the laundry. Miss Henderson is withdrawing from the work owing to her brother's death and other family rearrangements. Up to the present the crop prospects were never better and the garden is looking well.

In previous years I have urged the necessity of owning the land between us and the street. The Department sent their Inspector over it last year and he recommended the purchase but nothing has been done. I think it would be well if there was an agreement reached on this and other matters. They have put new desks in the classroom; are improving the hospital and have authorized the fitting up of the gymnasium. They wish us to move the sewing room. I think about a week's work with a carpenter and a small amount of material would do. The new arrangement would be better as it would be easier to keep the girls on their own side of the building.

I pointed out to you in previous letters that it would be
more economical for the church, more satisfactory to the Department and much easier for the principal if you could secure a man who could live in the school and whose wife could be matron. This might now be possible, as the principal does not need to be qualified for the ministry since the work on the reserve has been taken off. I would not recommend the building of a principal's residence at the school, but if such a step is considered, I would point out that there is a good residence nearby that can be bought cheaper than we could build. This house cannot be rent as the owner lives in it.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mrs. Clark:

Quite recently I visited Birtle Indian School. My attention was called to general condition of the Hospital department. The buildings are most unsatisfactory, especially that occupied by the nurse. This building is really unfit for occupation in winter time. The kitchen and wards are about 20x24, nurse's apartment 12x20, divided into two rooms. On the south side of each ward are verandahs, enclosed by wire screens, used for open air treatment. The wards might serve their purpose seeing that outdoor treatment is necessary in the majority of Indian cases. The floors, however, are in bad condition. The inside walls of all the buildings have been ceiled with lumber, put on before properly seasoned, and by no means free from knots. In many cases these knots have fallen out, leaving holes.

The nurse's room is a one-story building—poorly built; the inside ceiled, with unseasoned lumber, and in many places the shrinkage has resulted in cracks or openings. A single room, with four outside walls, and a poorly ceiled roof, cannot be made habitable, or comfortably so, in 40 below zero. It simply cannot be kept warm in winter. Everything liquid freeze the moment the fire declines, and in extreme cold, ordinary firing will not resist frost, even in daytime. If the nurse has much of a strain upon her, she ought to have at least a decently comfortable place in which to rest and sleep. The kitchen or work room is also intolerably cold in winter. A range stands in the centre, and beside it a large heater. The cooking range is not sufficient to prevent things freezing in the cupboard, or larder, in daytime, but has to be supplemented by the heater, in extreme weather.

It is difficult to make a suggestion. The wards might serve if repaired. The store room is not important. The other rooms should be reduced to lumber, and the lumber utilized in erecting a more comfortable structure. There is no reason why the kitchen, nurse's rooms and store room should not be arranged under one roof. The nurse's room need not be connected with the other parts, but the three rooms could be so built as not to have more than two outside walls. The one could protect the other. Fuel could be saved and comfort increased. The present condition is not in keeping with comfort, even to a decent degree. Nurse White was afraid to face the winter, and resigned last summer. Nurse Denny declares the rooms quite unfit for occupation. As you know her resignation is in. There may be other reasons as well for her resignation, but the fact remains that she considered the domicile unfit for winter occupation. The Government should put these buildings in comfortable condition before another winter. I feel confident that, if the Government
realized the actual condition, no pressure would be necessary. The Department I believe are anxious to have things right.

I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

S. C. Murray.

I have the honour to forward my report on the Birtle Boarding School, for the Quarter ended, December 31st, 1917, Birtle Agency as follows:

This school was inspected frequently during the quarter. The building was in good repair and the dormitories, kitchen, laundry, sewingroom and basement are kept in excellent order. The Gymnasium-room is used for calisthenics exercises and other drills, for both boys and girls. The stables and other outbuildings are kept clean and in fairly good condition.

The pupils are well clothed and neat and clean about their persons, and their table manners very good. Bed-clothing kept in good condition.

The sanitary and ventilation arrangements, are kept in good working order.

The water supply is sufficient for all necessary requirements in the school, also for fire purposes. The Cottage hospital also gets its supply from the school plant, but it has to be carried there in pails, which entails extra labour for the nurse, when bathing the patients.

The fire equipment seems to be in good condition and fire drill taught regularly. I have advised the Principal to have the fire-hose tested, so as to be sure, that there is no defects in it.

I think you will agree with me that a graduate nurse could not be actively engaged all the time at a small school like Birtle, unless in the case of some unforeseen epidemic; in such cases special provision may be necessary, as we made at File Hills recently when they had an epidemic of small-pox.

I have looked over the record of the Birtle school for a year past and find that they were almost entirely free from any serious sickness necessitating children being placed in the hospital for treatment. With the provision we have made for the treatment at Dynevor Hospital of special cases, I think the welfare of the children will be satisfactorily safeguarded. Might it not be possible to have the nurse at Portage la Prairie spend a portion of her time at Birtle, which is not far distant. This would be carrying out the policy originally agreed upon.

There is only one other institution in Canada at which a nurse is engaged at the expense of the Department, and that is the large industrial school at Brandon, with an enrolment of over 120 pupils, more than double the number at Birtle.

"Birtle Boarding School"

Situation:
The Birtle Boarding School is situated in the town of Birtle, Manitoba on the west bank of the Bird-Sail River.

Agency:
It is situated in the Birtle Indian agency, Treaty No. 1, J.A. Knott as the Indian agent.

Land:
There is 80 acres of land belonging to the school, of which five acres are under cultivation.

Religious:
This is a Presbyterian school and is conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church.

Buildings:
The school is a large grey stone building three stories high and also has a basement. It was built by the Presbyterian Church at a cost of $7000. The government did not give any grant toward building the school. It has ample accommodation for 45 pupils. The building is heated by two furnaces which burn cordwood. Beside the school building there is also a good sized barn, upon a stone foundation, which will accommodate 15 head of stock.
The Birtle Boarding School was started at the beginning of the first quarter 1888 and was conducted in the public school building which was closed from the town of Birtle for the summer. This seems to have been rented from the town up to the summer of 1889. In the Presbyterian Church built a new school of their own at a cost of $1000.

The first Govt grant given the school was in 1888-89 by an order in council dated 23rd May 1888. The amount paid each year they were granted an allowance of $60 per annum for each of 20 pupils. The amount of this grant actually paid the school for that year or till the end of the June quarter 1889 was $469.19.

The Estimates for the school were the same in 1889-90 as the previous year but only $26.42 of the grant was actually paid to the school.

In the Estimates for 1890-1 the grant was increased to 25 pupils @ $60 per annum. The school only received $927.50 of the amount voted during that year.

In 1891-92 the Grant was increased to $1410 being an allowance of $72.50 per capita for each pupil up to the number of 20. The school continued to be paid at this rate during the fiscal years of 1892-93 and 1893-94, also during the year 1894-95.
In 1895-96, the grant was increased and the estimates for that year provided for 25 pupils @ $7.00 per capita.

In 1896-97, the school was paid at the same rate as the preceding year viz.: 25 pupils @ $7.00 per capita.

In 1897-98, the estimates provided an allowance of $7.25 per capita for each of 40 pupils being an increase for 5 pupils over that of the two preceding years.

In 1898-99, the grant remained the same as in the preceding year of 1897-98.

Note: For all correspondence in regard to above increase in grants or in connection therewith see File 58, 2417/116, 624.

Facts of interest in the Bertha Body School:

On the 31st Dec. 1888, the Rev. Andrew Band Joint Commissioner of the Presbyterian Synod wrote the Comm. of Indian Affairs and among other matters stated that a Boarding or Industrial School had been opened at Bertha and was being conducted in the public school building which had been rented and fitted up for the purpose. He requested the Govt. to purchase the building which the town was willing to sell and place under the care of the Church for Boarding School purposes. The school was situated so far out of the town that it was inconvenient for the purpose for which it...
it was built and because of this circumstance it could be purchased at a price much below the original cost.

In a memo of the 6th June 89, the Deputy Chief of Indian Affairs stated that he could not entertain the proposal of giving assistance towards the erection or purchase of school buildings situated on land which does not belong to the Govt.

However, on the 16th Nov 89, the Dept wrote the Indian Comm at Regina instructing him to find out and report the value of the building and how much it would take to complete a similar one.

The Comm replied that he had procured the services of a contractor who valued the building and its site together with the site to be worth $9,000.00 and that a sum of $5,000.00 would be necessary to improve the building before it would be suitable for school purposes.

It was also of the opinion that a new building equal to the one now standing could not be erected for less than $9,000.00.

When the Supp. Estimates for 1891-2 were being prepared an amount of $10,000.00 was put in "for the erection of the building and purchase of necessary land" for the proposed Boarding School at Birtle but for some reason...
Some reasons were afterwards struck out. This fact shows that it was at that time the intention of the Court to give the Presbyterian Church a grant towards building the new school.

For further information on this point see letter dated May 18, 1894 on file No. 116, 624 to the Rev. Andrew Baird.

Also correspondence on Cowcotland File No. 116, 747.

Agent Marple in his report for 1894 says: "What a splendid stone building who completed and fairly well furnished and was occupied in October 1893 with an average of 30 pupils. Previous to that time the work was carried on in a building not well suited to such work." (This was probably the Public School Building which was first rented in 1888.)

In a letter to the West, dated April 6, 1894, Rev. Mr. Baird said that during the summer...
(continued)

Summary of 1893 a store building costing $7000 was erected in the town of Birtle at the expense of the Church.

Land again on the 7th January 1899 writing to the Dept he says that the land was purchased and the buildings erected entirely at the cost of the Presbyterian Church. (See plans of building on File No 116/674.)

Mr. Wadsworth in his report dated June 17th 95 on this school estimated the land, buildings etc. to be worth $7970.

The following bands are benefited by the school:

"Bird Jail" - Waywaysee Cappo
"Valley River" - Riding Mountain
Oak River and Oak Lake Band

The inspectors and agents in their reports invariably give the Birtle School a good report.

Dear Sir,

Some time ago you wrote me that one of the teachers at Birtle was not doing the proper quality of work. I took the matter up at once, with the result that the teacher of the senior room is being released, and the Committee is this week making an appointment of a teacher, re whom I will notify you a little later.

The particular item about which I wish to speak to you is this; I find that there has been a very serious mix up in regard to text books at Birtle School, and in justice to the outgoing teacher, I must state that I feel she has been in large measure a victim of circumstances, through not being furnished with proper text books. A very insufficient number of text books were on hand at the opening of the school, and the teacher had to manage with this insufficient equipment until such time as other books could be sent. When the books arrived, some one who had not sufficient knowledge of geography to realise where Birtle school was, sent on Ontario text books to be used under a Manitoba inspectorate, which naturally aroused the criticism of the Inspector and handicapped the pupils in having to change again to other text books in the middle of the term. In some subjects none of the text books arrived until the school year was nearly over. Is it any wonder that the pupils have shown very little progress this year? Why I was not informed of this earlier, I do not know, or I should have certainly kept the wires hot to Ottawa. I realise that with a change of administration and the death of Mr. Ferrier, and the multiplicity of details undertaken by those who were striving to carry on work new to them, that mistakes easily occur. It is too late this year to rectify the mistakes with the pupils, but I do wish to make this statement in justice to the teacher, as I feel that no teacher could have accomplished proper work in another term under such circumstances.
I hope you will note this in regard to Miss Manzer's work. At the same time, we are letting her out.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

With reference to the situation at the Birtle Residential School, as to the engineer, Mr Robert Ingram being discharged, I beg to report that acting on verbal instructions I received from the Deputy Superintendent General when I was in Ottawa, I have been to the school and discussed the condition of the heating and water systems with the Principal, Mr Currie. The newly appointed Principal, Rev; Mr Lockhart has not yet arrived at the school.

The high pressure boiler, from which is operated the steam dryer and other machinery in the laundry, is, in its present condition, absolutely useless, as all the flues are badly leaking. Mr Dunn, who has been placed in charge since Mr Ingram's dismissal, filled this boiler with cold water, and then began to apply some pressure, but before the gauge registered any pressure at all, the water was pouring out of the leaky flues.

The damage to the flues, is apparently just at the level at which the water rests when the boiler is in operation, and has evidently been caused by corrosion.

Mr Dunn had taken one flue out, and replaced it with a new one. On examining the flue taken out, I found that it was extremely thin in the walls, just at the water level.

Mr Principal Currie advised me that none of the boilers have been inspected by a boiler inspector since a year ago last spring. I therefore asked him to make arrangements to have them all inspected as soon as possible. It is compulsory that threshing engine boilers be inspected once.

Mr Principal Currie advises me that the present condition of this boiler is due to Mr Ingram's neglect, yet in a letter written by Mr A.G. If such is the case, it would appear that there has been some neglect on Principal Currie's part, in not having the matter attended to promptly when it was first reported to him. I have had no opportunity to get Mr Ingram's version, as he is at his home in Virden, and I have not seen him since my return to Birtle.

In the boiler in question, there are 48 flues one of which is a new one, and before any use can be made of it, it will have to be practically re-flued throughout. What this would cost, I do not as yet know, though I am writing to the Vulcan Iron Works Ltd of Winnipeg, the makers, to find out.

Dear Sir,

I herewith reply to your letter of March 14th,
No. 106-1-1.

Parents and other relatives of the children of our school have never been denied an opportunity of visiting their children since I became Principal. They have not always seen them at the time they asked, and that because of the children being occupied in the classroom or on other duty, but they have never had to return home without this privilege being granted them. I have repeatedly said that it is most natural that they should desire to see their own. On different occasions we have provided a sleeping place in a small room where brooms and scrub pails are stored, and that at an inconvenience to ourselves. I have also let men sleep inside boiler room. I can find no sleeping accommodation provided by the Department in the erection of this building. If there is such I would like to be shown it. There is one small room in which we store flour, etc., that I am told by members of our staff was intended for a meeting place for parents and children. This I found used for a store room when I took over the work, not knowing for some time but that that was the purpose for which it was there. These people have been given seating accommodation in a large hall to visit their children and in many cases have been allowed to be with them in the playrooms.

When Indians, married and unmarried, young and old, men and women, boys and girls, come here and ask for sleeping accommodation, any number from one to a dozen at a time, what am I to do but tell them that I am sorry, but the Department has not provided accommodation for them, and that in coming to visit with the intention of remaining they must provide their own.

This Mrs. Robert Bone, who asked lawyer Richardson to write you, has landed in here off the train a number of times without sending any word ahead. We have always made her comfortable and treated her well. She has remained several days at a
time. Once in the midst of her stay here, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bone came off the train and asked for sleeping quarters. They thought it would be all right for the three to sleep in the broom room, which of course I did not agree to, and in a way that apparently caused no offence, I told Mr. Bone the best we could give him was a place in the furnace room.

Never have any of the Indians endeavored, before leaving home, to arrange with me for accommodation. They have, as it were, forced themselves upon me and I could not turn them out in the cold. I only wish a representative of your Department could have been here at certain times and could have seen for himself.

Then in the matter of meals, apart from the question of sleeping quarters - those who stay at nights walk into our children's dining room for their three meals a day; but here is an instance from the nearest Reserve. One Saturday five people of one family connection came to the school arriving shortly before noon. Of their own accord they walked into our dining room. We made room for them and gave them their dinner without uttering a complaint. The next Saturday at 11.40 a.m., ten people of the same family connection came. I felt obliged to tell them that we were not prepared for them, which I did after speaking to Agent Lazenby over the phone.

Let me mention this important matter. We are trying to do our best for the health and cleanliness of our children. When these children come to us from the Reserves, whether it be their first admission to the school or their return after holidays, they have to be thoroughly examined and cleansed as for vermin and skin troubles, etc. The risk is great enough through the granting the privilege of a brief visitation, but think of our anxiety when these people come and live amongst the children for days and even weeks.

You have asked about visiting hours for parents. I have not arranged such, but, as you see I have never refused the privilege. It will certainly be to our advantage to have definite hours, and I would be pleased to receive and consider suggestions you might offer in this connection.

As for the suggestion you received, re the providing of a shanty for their winter accommodation, I would suggest that if you make a move of this kind you provide two separate places, one for each sex, as you certainly do not want any opening for the bringing of disgrace upon the School and Institution, and that these places be carefully supervised.

In the matter of their stay, whether in tents or in the above mentioned places, I think there should be a limit. I think they might well be limited to two days. Some have stayed here I believe as much as a month at a time. Under these circumstances
we cannot do the best for the children; they are in a very unsettled state of mind while this lasts as to their studies and other duties. They want their children with them a part of every day they are here. And think of these children sitting and lying on the filthy blankets in those Indian tents.

As for the poster that was sent to the Reserves bearing the signature of Mr. Lavendar and myself. That was framed by Mr. Lavendar who told me he could speak for the Department in the matter as the Department has voiced itself really in the erection of a building with no sleeping quarters provided for the parents.

All this I respectfully submit.

Yours very truly,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, regarding the matter of visiting hours and accommodation provided for Indian parents visiting their children at the Birtle Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say the matter of visiting hours and accommodation for Indians at Indian residential schools is left in the hands of the Principal and staff of the schools. It is necessary, in the interests of the work at the school, that definite regulations be made, setting forth the time when parents will be permitted to visit their children. I would suggest the afternoon of the weekly holiday from classroom activities - probably Saturday in your case.

From the information contained in your letter, it is considered you are being imposed upon by the Indians in furnishing them with meals and in the length of time they remain at the school. You should set certain hours each week for Indian parents to visit their children and adhere to them.

Indians who come from a distance might be permitted to remain over night but not for a longer period. The Indian parents from the nearby reserves should not be given meals and should not be allowed to remain on the premises over night. Of course, there will be exceptions to the above, and you will have to use your own discretion in the matter. Your school should certainly not be called

upon to provide meals to Indian parents from the reserves near the school.

The indiscriminate visits by parents or relatives are not in the best interests of the health and cleanliness of the children and upset the regular school routine. You should take a strong stand in discouraging Indian parents and relatives of the pupils remaining several days at a time; and this practice should not continue.

Regarding the providing of sleeping accommodation for over-night Indians, I would say that, during the warm weather, they should provide their own tents and blankets. In cold weather, you will, no doubt, be able to arrange accommodation, either in the school building or in the outbuildings, for an Indian who remains over night. The Indians should be definitely informed that they cannot remain for a longer period than one night, and their visit should conform to the periods set apart by you for parents to visit their children.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of Dec. 21st last, (No. 291-11B) regarding conditions in the Birtle School,

The girls in the school have had no sport and hardly any outdoor exercise all winter. Last month I was up there, and quite a percentage of the girls had old leather boots on which were quite unfit to go outdoors in during the winter months. During the play hours they just hang around in the basement playrooms. I pointed out to Mr. Lockhart the condition of their footwear and he agreed that many of them were unfit for wear, and stated that he did not know that they were in that condition. A few days ago I was up there and am glad to say that quite a number of new boots were in evidence. Mr. Lockhart has promised to have a toboggan slide and some skates for the girls next winter. I am of the opinion that these children should be outdoors for a certain time daily, when the weather is fit, especially as they are subject to T.B., and it is surprising to me that such a condition should exist in an Indian School. Many of the Indian mothers know how beneficial fresh air and exercise are to their children, and see that they get it when possible.

Despite this the children have enjoyed excellent health all winter. The boys have had very good sport on their rink. The boys have also had good footwear all winter, though when I was up there last month about 70% had no laces in their rubber boots, which made them look anything but tidy. That is remedied now however.

My opinion is that the Church have lost the services of a very efficient Pastor, in appointing Mr. Lockhart Principal of the School, and have not obtained a good Principal. Mr. Lockhart is a very fine man, and does his best, but I do not think that he understands children, and he does not seem able to enlist the co-operation of his staff.

Mrs. Hilliard
Mrs. Hilliard is still there, and I am sure that Mr. Lockhart does not desire to have her on the staff, as there is continual friction between them.

I am told that Inspector Clarke has recommended that Mr. McLeod the teacher, be replaced in the summer, and I am sure that that is a move in the right direction, though I am not in a position to judge his work in the class room.

I do not like to criticize the work of the School, and really do not feel qualified to do so, but I am sure that the girl pupils have not had a chance all winter, to be reasonably happy and contented. Five of them ran away last month. Fortunately they were caught only five miles from the school. They tied sheets together and slid out of a dormitory window. To be candid I cannot blame the girls, as the life they have been leading is enough to breed discontent.

When the weather improves, I am sure that Mr. Lockhart will try to get these girls interested in some form of sport.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) A. G. Smith

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo No. 201-11, requesting a detailed report on the Staff of the Birtle Residential School. I really do not feel qualified to report on the Staff, and feel that the Principal is in a much better position to do so than I am.

There is not sufficient co-operation between the Principal and some of the members of the Staff, and I am sure that this lack of co-operation creates an atmosphere that is detrimental to the work of the School. I do not know who is to blame for this. Mr. Lockhart, the Principal does not seem to have the confidence of some members of the Staff. The ladies are over-worked and have not sufficient time for recreation and relaxation. When they are not on duty, they are too tired to take any interest in affairs outside the School, which is a pity, as such a condition tends to make them lose interest in their work.

I feel that Mr. Lockhart spends too much of his time and energy on the School Farm, which work could be done very well by the Farming Instructor. I doubt whether Mrs. Lockhart is able to take her full share of the duties on account of ill health.

The other members of the Staff are as follows:

Miss Bright; Boys Matron. Miss Bright has given very faithful service for some years in Indian work. She is well liked and respected by the children, and in fact by everyone with whom she comes in contact. On account of her age she is finding the work hard now, and will soon retire I think.

Mrs. Hilliard; Girls Matron. I do not think that Mrs. Hilliard has a suitable disposition for the work, and think that any Principal would find her hard to manage.

Miss Bray; Teacher. A splendid teacher who was giving excellent service until her health broke down. Unfortunately I do not think that she will ever be physically fit for this work.

Dear Mr. St. John:

Your letter of November 10, addressed to the Minister of this Department, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I may state the records indicate that the desirability of establishing Indian day schools on the reserves to which you refer in your communication has been carefully reviewed and considered by the Department on a number of occasions. This matter was given very careful thought prior to the rebuilding of the Birtle Residential School, in the fiscal year 1920-31. At this date there is a very persistent demand for the establishment of a Roman Catholic day school on the Waywayseecappo reserve. I may state, however, that the difficulties in the way of establishing Indian day schools on these reserves are almost insurmountable.

Subsection 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act reads: "No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices".

If a Roman Catholic school were established on the Waywayseecappo reserve, the demand would immediately arise for the establishment of a Protestant school, and the existence of these schools would seriously jeopardize,

C. L. St. John, Esq., K.C.,
Barrister,
Minnedosa, Manitoba.
as you state, the heavy investment at the Birtle Residential School.

It is my personal opinion that the policy of the Government with respect to the education of the Indian population will move gradually toward the multiplication of Indian day schools on reserves, and it is just possible that in the future a number of residential schools may be organized to provide vocational instruction for senior pupils. The present policy, however, cannot be changed overnight.

Principals of Indian residential schools were instructed in departmental circular dated January 15, 1937, that at least one third of the school period should be devoted to manual or vocational instruction—Elementary agriculture, gardening, care of live stock, blacksmithing, carpentry and auto mechanics for boys and hand loom weaving, dressmaking, fruit preserving, crochet work, etc., for girls.

Inspector Sigvaldason, in his last report on the Birtle Residential School, dated January 12, 1937, states in part as follows:

"Mr. Carmichael is doing good work with classes in woodworking. All pupils get practical work. The girls do sewing, laundry work, kitchen duties and other household services, while the boys are engaged in work outside. I was particularly pleased to see the interest taken in the outdoor rink. The boys have a couple of excellent hockey teams. This year they played with teams from neighboring towns. A music teacher is on full time duty at the school. The pupils who are musical are given every opportunity to develop their talent".

It is my intention to ask the public school inspector to make a special inspection of the Birtle School and report to the Department. Just as soon as this report reaches me, I shall be glad to communicate with you again. In addition to this, I am today communicating with Home Mission -
Mission Board of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, intimating that a certain amount of dissatisfaction exists with respect to the studies provided at the Birtle institution. The costs at the Birtle School are the highest in the Dominion, and there is no reason whatever why a worthwhile course should not be provided for the pupils in attendance.

I have noted with interest the Indians' reference to the Treaties and certain provisions contained therein for the education of their children. I know of no provisions in these Treaties other than the provision that adequate educational facilities shall be provided for the Indian population.

Yours very truly,

Director.

Lockhart has resigned from the principalship of the Birtle Indian Residential School. We have now been informed by Miss J. Florence Lang, Secretary of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, that Mr. A. E. Candy has been appointed acting principal.

The Department is fully aware that you will be very busily engaged during the weeks immediately ahead of us in the organization of your farm program and with your general duties. Nevertheless, it would be appreciated if you could find the time necessary to make a couple of inspections of the Birtle Residential School between now and the end of the present school year. Miss Lang, in her letter, intimates that if Mr. Candy's work during this period is satisfactory, the Board would be willing to appoint him permanently. In view of this fact, it is of the utmost importance that we should have, from one of our own senior officials, an unbiased report on Mr. Candy's fitness for the position and an expression of opinion in respect to the success that he is likely to make of the administration of the Birtle School should be secure the appointment. I have intimated to Miss Lang that it is our intention to make the courses of study at Indian residential schools increasingly more vocational and practical in character and that the principal of the Birtle School, in our judgment -

I have also suggested to her that Mr. Candy, or the principal that may be appointed, should visit one or two schools in Canada and perhaps one or two schools in the United States where vocational studies have been organized on a satisfactory basis.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Miss Lang:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 13th instant, in which you intimate that the Board of the Women's Missionary Society have decided to appoint Mr. A. E. Candy as acting principal of the Birtle Indian Residential School. It is noted also that you have asked Mrs. Lockhart to continue as matron until June. In view of all the circumstances, this arrangement appears to be satisfactory to the Department and is therefore approved.

However, I should like to have an opportunity to discuss with you the principalship of the Birtle School prior to the appointment of a permanent principal. It may be exceedingly difficult, in view of existing conditions, to secure a suitable man for the position. Mr. Candy may be in many respects suitable, but my information in regard to him, his teaching ability, training and general background is somewhat limited.

We are engaged at the present time in the organization and promotion of worthwhile vocational courses at our residential schools throughout the Dominion. We have recently employed an official who is definitely responsible for the promotion and extension of these courses of study. The Minister has long since been of the opinion that the courses of study provided at our residential schools are altogether too -
