Sir:

I beg to submit the following report for the month of February 1948.

The Rev. E.H. Lockhart, Principal of the Birtle Residential School, resigned on January 31st. Since that time Mr. A. Candy, the senior class room teacher, has been acting Principal, and has filled the position very well so far. There have been some truants, but they have run away for no apparent cause. Mr. Candy has already made some improvements in the building, having had a good deal of work done on the plumbing, where it was out of order. He has also had the boys do some painting in the interior of the building, which has brightened it up a lot. A new engineer has been appointed and I think he will take good care of the plant.

A.G. Smith,
Indian Agent.
Dear Sir:

I acknowledge your letter of February 20, 1942, File 106-1-1, and would report as follows in connection with the Birtle Indian Residential School and its Acting Principal, Mr. A. E. Candy.

Mr. Candy is a man about 32 years of age, but he appears much younger. Previous to taking over the duties of Acting Principal, he held the position of senior teacher. Mr. Candy has a pleasing personality and is a man of high ideals. He is interested in young people, and most considerate of the children. I think Mr. Candy would make an excellent principal, provided he can enforce discipline.

Since taking over his duties he has had many minor repairs carried out, and also has had the boys do considerable interior painting. He has engaged the village blacksmith to teach blacksmithing in a class of boys one-half day a week. Already splendid results have been obtained, and I cannot speak too highly of this work.

Meat for the school is purchased from the town butcher. Arrangements have been made for two boys at a time to learn from this butcher how to cut this meat, make sausage, and in fact do all kinds of work relating to butchering. This is a line of work which should prove useful.

A music teacher from Birtle has also been engaged to teach piano lessons to a number of girls, and violin lessons to 5 or 6 boys. This is a change from the regular program of studies and is apparently enjoyed by the pupils.

Recently a Mr. Dickenson has been engaged as farming instructor. I was greatly impressed with this man, and feel confident there will be a marked improvement in farming methods. Mr. Dickenson is also interested in gardening, and proposes planting a large vegetable garden. This school has no root cellar and one should be provided. Mr. Candy states he is prepared to arrange for all the labor if the Department will provide the material. It is estimated this material will cost about $150.00. I understand that in past years only a summer garden was grown, and winter vegetables were purchased as required due to the fact that no cellar was available. I urge that a cellar be authorized and the necessary funds provided.

Mr. Candy also wishes to improve the grounds, and grade and gravel the drive leading to the highway. This will entail considerable work and it will be necessary to purchase a quantity......

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
a quantity of gravel. I would recommend that $75.00 be allowed to help pay for some extra help and the gravel.

Many Indian parents visit the school. There is no accommodation and they are obliged to sleep in the hall leading to the Chapel. On Saturday there were six visitors, one of whom was quite sick and later had to be removed to the hospital. This situation should not exist. It disrupts the school, makes it more difficult to keep the place clean, and is a means of bringing sickness into the school. It is also a financial burden involving added expense for food. Mr. Candy is prepared, with his farmer and the boys, to erect a small log house to accommodate the parents, if the Department will assist in providing the lumber and windows, at a total estimated cost of perhaps $150.00. The work will be good training for the boys. The parents will then be able to come only when room is available, and will be required to bring their own blankets and food.

There are still two percheron stallions cared for at the stables. Mr. Candy and the farming instructor both agree that these animals are not necessary and should be sold. I advised Mr. Candy to secure a buyer if possible, and sell the animals.

The boys' supervisor at this school is a man well past 60 years of age, and in my opinion is not suitable for the position. A young man familiar with sports, with the ability to enforce discipline and yet be a leader, should be appointed. I doubt if such a man can be found at the present salary, which I understand is $40.00 per month plus allowance. Ordinary farm labor receives this wage.

The senior room is now in the charge of a lady teacher, and again I think this is a mistake. A man teacher with experience is required. If suitable help were provided in this classroom, and an alert and active disciplinarian appointed as boys' supervisor, then Mr. Candy would have a fair opportunity to show whether he can handle the situation.

The following facts came to light during my discussion with Mr. Candy, which I think amply justify my claim that discipline is now the essential requirement at the school:

A few of the older boys are very unruly. At times they are disrespectful to the staff and refuse to obey.

Several children have run away, and Mr. Candy is afraid to punish these children when they are insolent or disobedient for fear they will leave again.

Some boys complain openly about the food, and recently one boy said the sausage was unfit for food and threw his on the floor and stepped on it. The sausages were fresh and made from clean wholesome meat. Some of the children refuse to eat eggs and so Mr. Candy now serves them only about once a week. At present they gather about 150 eggs daily. I advised Mr. Candy to serve eggs at least 3 times a week, but suggested he might have them cooked differently for each serving. At present the boys apparently pick and choose their food, and in my opinion their likes and dislikes are given too much consideration.

Recently the boys broke into the storeroom and stole considerable canned food and bread. They make skeleton keys and apparently do not hesitate to use them for any purpose.

They know......
They know they are stealing but seem to have little regard for honesty. I am convinced all this is due to lack of proper supervision by people who know how to discipline children; and further, that the pupils have too much idle time without supervision. The idle hours should be employed in supervised wholesome sport.

Frankly, I was amazed and shocked at what I saw, and unless this tide of discontent and disregard for order and honesty is checked, the staff will have no control over the children; and the older pupils returning to the reserves will constitute a real problem.

I again recommend the appointment of a boys' supervisor and also an experienced male teacher for the senior classroom. Both appointments require men who understand children and can enforce strict discipline. If these changes are made at once, perhaps by June 30th one could speak with more accuracy as to the wisdom of appointing Mr. Candy as principal. At present the outlook is not good but I feel Mr. Candy has been greatly handicapped by certain members of his staff and this throws altogether too heavy a burden on him. Again I point out that Mr. Candy has many excellent qualities and is a hard worker. He is anxious to make good and there is evidence of close cooperation between him and Mr. Smith, the Indian Agent. At present the strain is heavy, due to the lack of discipline and the long hours of work. The changes suggested should greatly relieve the situation.

As requested, I will visit the school again late in June, after which a further report will be submitted.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
March 30, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 27th instant with reference to your recent visit to the Birtle Residential School. The insubordination on the part of the pupils is very disturbing and I am communicating with the Secretary of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church and recommending that a new boys' supervisor be obtained immediately.

We are prepared to consider purchasing the material required for the root cellar and you should forward a requisition for what is required.

We are also prepared to favourably consider the expenditure of $75.00 for graveling the drive leading to the highway.

From our experience at other schools, I do not think that it is advisable to proceed immediately with the erection of a building to provide accommodation for parents visiting their children at the school. Conditions existing at present in this particular regard should not be allowed to continue and everything humanly possible should be done to discourage parents from visiting their children except on one, or possibly two, special afternoons each week. Certainly the Acting Principal should immediately discontinue allowing parents to sleep at the school over night. If a building for their accommodation were erected it would only aggravate this condition. It is quite

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Birtle Indian School

I am very glad that Inspector Hamilton has visited Birtle and made such a full report. Our Board thinks that Mr. Candy has done exceedingly well in very trying circumstances.

We advertised in a Winnipeg paper about two or three weeks ago for a male teacher but had no replies at all. We are again advertising in Winnipeg and one other Western paper. Possibly the salary offered - $650.00 was not attractive enough. We are prepared to offer more but will ask applicants to state salary as it is a matter of getting a good man.

I knew that the boys' Supervisor, Mr. Herron, was rather old and I am writing to Mr. Candy asking him to look for a young man with the required qualifications at once, and to offer a larger salary, probably $60.00, as he does not need the teacher's standing.

Birtle has been unfortunate in having so many changes. We expect to put Miss MacKay into deaconess work after the summer holidays, so we shall have to find another junior teacher. We are glad that Mr. Hamilton approved of the new farm instructor. We have had to increase his salary to $80.00 with house and meals for himself. Formerly the farmer was paid $40.00 with house and meals but we think the farm will show better results under this new man. We are glad to have the extra allowance as this will help with the increased salaries. Mrs. Lockhart asked for an increase in salary but the Board has decided that it would not be wise to continue her appointment if Mr. Candy is to get the appointment permanently and she will be needed in the manse if Mr. Lockhart accepts the Church.

I hope these facts will relieve your anxiety about Birtle and I would like to assure you that we shall do everything we possibly can to help Mr. Candy. With a capable staff we are sure he will be able to enforce discipline.

Indians Secretary.

P.S. We shall be very glad to see you whenever you come to Toronto.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from Mr. A. G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, Manitoba.

The Birtle school, to which the agent refers, is a government-owned institution. The records indicate that this school was built in 1930 and that the farm consists of 655 acres. The building is fireproof.

The officials of the Welfare and Training Service are of the opinion that it would not be difficult to provide day school accommodation for the 115 pupils enrolled at this date at Birtle. In view of these facts, the suggestion made by the members of the Waywayseecappo Band might be carefully considered in connection with accommodation for the group of Japanese now resident in British Columbia, who appear to be suffering from certain physical disabilities. There is an objection, however, to the use of this particular school for the care of Japanese, that should not be overlooked. The school buildings are quite close to the town of Birtle, I should think not more than a quarter of a mile from the town boundaries. This fact might not constitute an insurmountable obstacle if the building were used for the care of invalids.

Encl.

Director.

Dear Sirs:

Re: Rolling River and Elphinstone Indian Reserves and Re: Birtle Indian School Accommodation.

Chief Jim Wilson and Councillor Shannacappo of the Rolling River Reserve and Chief George Bone and Councillor David Burns of Elphinstone Reserve have asked me to write to you in connection with the matters mentioned in a letter received by them from Mr. Smith, Indian Agent at Birtle, respectively bearing date 9th April, 1942, of which I am here-with enclosing you a copy.

These parties speak on behalf of the Indians on their respective reserves, stating that they are satisfied to provide their own accommodation when they visit their children at Birtle during the summer months, say from April to October inclusive, along the lines mentioned in said letter of April 9th.

They, however, feel that these regulations should be relaxed during the winter months from November to the following March when they, owing to weather conditions, usually find it very difficult or impossible to travel back and forth to the Birtle Indian School and to provide their sleeping accommodation during such period. There are only three trains per week from Basswood to Birtle going west on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays and returning on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays and travelling is rendered still more awkward by the fact that the buses are now being removed from the highways. They have already been removed from the Elphinstone to Russell highway and it seems a strong probability that these buses may be taken off the Minnedosa to Russell highway as well before very long.

These Indians are anxious to retain the right to visit their children during the winter time and state that
they would be satisfied to visit not more than twice during the said five winter months. These people are very fond of their children and a good many of them appear to be loath to send their children to the Indian School unless they can visit them during the winter months. They would like particularly to visit the children at Christmas time, and upon the occasions of their visits during the cold months they wish to have sleeping accommodation and meals while there. The visits would not, in most cases, last more than a day, and I believe that the accommodation and meals furnished are the simplest and most inexpensive in character. Evidently if the Saturday afternoon rule is insisted upon throughout the winter that would practically amount to forbidding the Indians to visit at all during the winter months. I asked these parties if they knew of any sickness which had been brought into the School upon the occasion of any such visits but they stated that they did not think that any diseases had ever been brought in in that manner so far as they knew.

They also think that the Chief and Councillor of each Reserve should not be limited in their visits like the parents and relatives, as they appear to feel a special responsibility for the well-being and education of the children and think that accordingly they should be allowed to visit whenever they want to check up conditions in the school so that they may be at any time in the position to report conditions back to the Reserve Indians.

These parties have also got the opinion from reading the Treaties with the Queen recorded in an old copy of the Treaty Book in their possession, that the Indian School should be built and operated upon the Indian Reserves. I explained to them that these Treaties had probably been altered by a Statute or by a Department regulation so as to provide for teaching the Indians in central schools like the Birtle School. I would appreciate your advising me as to the legal situation in this respect and, if possible, you might give me a reference to the relevant Statutory provisions and regulations in this connection.

I hope that it will be possible to meet these Indians requests as to accommodation of visitors somewhat along the lines above proposed, and will be glad if you would write me advising as to what can be done to modify the existing situation.

Yours very truly,

C. L. St. John

On the 12th inst Mr Webb the Principal of the Birtle Residential School, was taking a load of pupils from the school out to the field to do a little stocking by truck. He met a car on the way, which apparently would not give him his share of the road, so he turned into the ditch to prevent a collision, and the truck upset. Dear Sir:

In any event, it is almost unbelievable that the principal should permit 70 pupils to be conveyed in a truck.

The action you have taken appears to be about all you can do at the present time. In your own interests, however, and in the interests of the Department, you should notify the Principal in writing that this practice must be discontinued immediately and that so long as he occupies his present position he will be held definitely responsible for the care and wellbeing of the pupils committed to his care. I am sorry this matter was not reported to you. This particular theft was not so cut and dried as it appears, and the agent and I are still winding up the affair. I have been negligent in not reporting the affair as it progressed; but, I thought it would be better to report it in its entirety rather than piecemeal.

May 22nd was a Saturday. Mr. Drey had recommended that the parents be allowed their children one day a week to a day that would not interfere too greatly with the school's program. These first Saturdays have been parent days for at least a year and a half. May 24th always brings the parents in large numbers to the school. It has been one of the "big" days of the year for quite some time. The parents arrived on the twenty-first. They had their children all day Saturday and visited them all day Sunday at the school, and had them again all day Monday the twenty-fourth. Then parents had their families with them including boys over and under school age. These older boys had at least two bicycles. These boys have ridden to the school on them many times during the...
year. While here, they lend their bicycles to the school pupils. Therefore, it is a common sight to see the boys on a bicycle over the weekend, and the staff members thought nothing of it.

The senior boys have been allowed to go downtown on Saturday nights for some years. They usually attend a show which starts at half past seven and ends towards ten o'clock. They are usually home by ten. There is only one staff member detailed for duty on Saturday evenings; and, he remains at the school to supervise the junior boys and to put them to bed. On Sunday afternoons, the engineer, boys' supervisor, headman and the male teacher take turns supervising the boys just as they take turns every evening of the week; and, every Sunday morning and evening.

On Saturday, May 22nd, the bicycles were here. The owner of the bicycles (older Indian boys) rode some of our lads downtown (1 mile down hill) on them. Lloyd was one of them. He spoke with an Indian lad from Roseau whose name is Milton Lennard. After the show Milton and Lloyd started school. After the show Milton and Lloyd started home. They called in at a livery barn for a drink from the well. Leaning against the door was a bicycle which they thought was the one Lloyd had ridden downtown on. They decided...

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, requesting that the children attending the Birtle Residential School be allowed to go to their homes for the holiday period between Christmas and New Year's Day.

The Department has always taken the position that the allowing of holidays during the winter is neither in the best interests of the pupils themselves nor conducive to the progress of residential schools. Pupils residing close to the school might be allowed home for Christmas Day only, provided they will return to the school the same evening. As a matter of fact, we have always encouraged residential schools to arrange some special celebration, either on Christmas Day or one of the days in Christmas week, and have the parents come to the school and spend the day with their children.

In view of our policy, which has been in effect for several years, the Department cannot see its way clear to allow the pupils from the Birtle School the privilege that you request.

Yours truly,

Acting Director.

I inspected the Birtle Indian Residential School on December 6th, 1944.

There are 108 children enrolled and three classrooms are now in operation. The juniors or beginners are in charge of Miss Hamilton. She has thirteen beginners and fifteen in Grade 1. Mr. Frost has the intermediate grades listed as follows:

| Grade | Pupils |
|-------|--------|
| 2     | 18     |
| 3     | 16     |

Miss Kenney has the senior room and the grades are as follows:

| Grade | Pupils |
|-------|--------|
| 4     | 15     |
| 5     | 16     |
| 6     | 13     |
| 7     | 1      |

There is one grade 9 pupil attending the Birtle Public School.

The classrooms are bright and airy. The children were clean, with the girls dressed in uniform. The work seen was well done and I am confident the children are making fair progress. Miss Kenney is greatly interested in her work. She has a bright, cheerful personality and is full of energy. Mr. Webb is fortunate in having her on his staff.

The kitchen is well equipped and the girls receive excellent training. The meals are well prepared and there is plenty for all. Mr. Webb, the Principal, believes the farm should produce most of the required food for the school and so nothing is sold. The milk is used for the children and for butter. Beef, pork and eggs are seen in abundance, and the vegetable crop was excellent. He also has turkeys and poultry sufficient for Christmas dinner for all.

The school garden was excellent. The potato crop yielded about 1400 bushels. In addition there was an excellent crop of onions, turnips, cabbage, parsnips and carrots. The root cellar is built in the side of the hill and due to the excessive soil rains is too damp. The result is the vegetables are not keeping well. Serious consideration should be given to building a suitable cellar with ample storage space. Abundance of vegetables is essential at all our schools and the need for a suitable root cellar should receive first consideration.

The laundry equipment appears in fair condition and the sample of work seen spoke well for the girls' training.

The dormitories were all tidy and well aired. The beds were neatly made and the bedding of good quality and clean. The fire escapes' exits are convenient and all extinguishers charged ready for use.
In the sewing-room the senior girls were busy making new uniforms. These uniforms are made in a nice style from a blue material trimmed with red. The work was neat and the sewing good.

The furnace room was tidy and the equipment all in working condition. The filter, cold water pressure tank and the underground outside tank have given good service; but at any time renewals may be required. These tanks are all badly pitted and just how much longer they will last is a question. The renewal of any one will cost in the neighborhood of five hundred dollars.

The boys half of the infirmary is dark, as there is only one window. This room could be improved if the walls and ceiling were painted a light shade. Mr. Webb planned a special scheme of color for both rooms in the infirmary and had purchased special wall stencils, hoping the Department would furnish the paint; but for some reason the paint specified for this work was omitted. I would recommend that it be supplied, as sick rooms, especially for children, should be bright and cheerful. The requirements are:

- 6 gals. turquoise, flat wall $10 Silkstone
- 1 " shell pink, " " $11 "

The Principal's residence should be re-papered downstairs. There is a large hall, a dining-room and a large living room. The paper and labor will cost approximately $75.00. I would recommend Mr. Smith, the Indian Agent at Birtle, be allowed authority to proceed with the work.

The two main barns have been painted and are in good repair. The hog barn, chicken house and machine shed remain to be painted and the paint required will cost about $75.00. This work should be done next year without fail.

The stock are all in good condition. Twelve cows are milking at present and others will freshen during the coming year. At present Mr. Webb has over 60 hogs and he informed me all would be used for the school.

The staff all are greatly interested in their work and a fine spirit of cooperation exists. Mr. Webb, with his wife as Matron, is doing a splendid work. I am confident the children are well fed, well clothed and happy.

I have your letter No.106-1-1 of the 2nd inst.regarding the question of accommodation for Indian parents when visiting their children at Birtle Residential School. This matter does cause dissatisfaction amongst the Indians of all the Reserves. The Roman Catholic Schools do provide some accommodation for the parents, and I am sure that they make them comfortable and provide for them to some extent when they visit the schools. The Roman Catholic children from this Agency attend Pine Creek and Sandy Bay Schools, which are situated a considerable distance from the Reserves, and therefore there is not much danger of the parents making a nuisance of themselves there, which they would do at the Birtle School, as it is not so far from the Reserves. I have never visited Sandy Bay or Pine Creek school, but I know that the parents go there by train in winter without making any provision for their own accommodation.

Two children from Rolling River Reserve were enrolled as pupils at Sandy Bay School last fall, mainly because the guardians could visit them there, and the Missionary does not of course approve of that as he is Presbyterian. In this case the Guardians, who I think are really Pagans, signed a declaration that they desired the children to be brought up in the Roman Catholic faith.

Personally I think there should be some accommodation for parents at the schools, but of course visiting would have to be curtailed, and controlled carefully. I do not think that the Indians will ever be satisfied until they have day schools on the Reserves, on this Agency, and judging the work of the school by the ex-pupils over a period of years, we cannot be satisfied with the result ourselves, and we cannot convince...
the Indians that Residential Schools are really doing something for their children until we can show them some satisfactory results.

During the past year pupils in Birtle Residential School are attending classes all day, and I think that under this system, some results can be shown in a few years.

I submit the following report on the Sirtle Indian Residential School, inspected May 6th, 1946.

There are 107 pupils enrolled - girls 52, and boys 54. They are arranged in three classrooms, beginners or juniors, intermediate and seniors. The classroom work seen was well done and I am confident that the children are making fair progress. The children were neatly dressed and clean. The classrooms were well aired and very tidy.

The sewing room is well supervised and the senior girls do excellent work. They can make their own dresses, knit and do excellent fancy work. Some of the sewing machines are in poor condition and need repairing. I would recommend that one new Singer Sewing Machine be supplied.

The dormitories were clean and the beds neatly made. There appeared ample bedding. The toilets were clean and all in working order.

Mr. Rusaw, the Principal, has with the assistance of the boys done considerable painting. The colour scheme is excellent and the painting has been carefully done. At present they are doing the staff living room. The chesterfield and two chairs are very shabby and should be replaced. The covering is badly worn and the springs useless. I strongly recommend the purchase of a new chesterfield and two chairs to match.

Battleship linoleum has been used to cover the rough cement floors in the main hall, Principal's office and in the infirmary. This along with the painting has effected a wonderful change which I am confident is appreciated by all. The school interior is now bright and attractive. There are still rooms to paint as well as dormitories, and no doubt more paint will be required. The painting has been a real training for the boys and they can be justly proud of their work.

The playrooms and washrooms have also been thoroughly cleaned and painted. The taps and plumbing are all in good condition.

The Principal would like to build some cupboards and make a large table for the sewing room. He is prepared to do the work if the material can be supplied. I told him to secure a bill of material and this will be forwarded for consideration when received.

At present 12 cows are milking and there are more to freshen. The pigs number all told about 60. Last week the Principal sold 15 for which he received $204.00. He expected to sell another 15 this week. Of the balance six or eight will be butchered for meat and the rest sold late in June.

The Principal, Mr. HEBB, occupies a suite of rooms on the main floor of the building, and the engineer, Mr. FINDLAY, has a room in the basement. Mr. HEBB could not be interviewed this date as he was away on a reservation in Saskatchewan for a load of children to start the fall term. Mr. FINDLAY could offer no information of value. He stated he was in bed before midnight Saturday, and he heard nothing whatever until time to get up Sunday morning. He could suggest no possible suspects at all, having seen nobody loitering around the school recently whatever. He said the children sleeping in the school just now could be entirely trusted, and the theft must have been committed by an outsider.

Miss Ray ANDERSON was next questioned, and she told of being awakened about 4:00 a.m. Sunday, and seeing a big Indian standing in her room by her bed. She was badly frightened, and screamed frantically. The Indian turned and ran, and there was just sufficient light for her to say that he was wearing a red and tan two-tone sweater, similar to a hockey sweater, with a spot on the back which could have been a number. She was so frightened that she only took time to slam her door shut and then she jumped back into bed and stayed there until morning.

The little girls sleeping in the dormitory at the West end of the corridor stated they did not hear anything during the night at all. They are only young children, about eight and nine years, respectively, and all members of the school staff state that they are beyond suspicion.

Eric HILLIER, the asleep at the East end of the corridor, was next interviewed. He was questioned at some length, but could give no definite information. He said he heard nothing at all during the night in question, but slept soundly until morning. When he heard of the money being stolen from Miss HEBB, and of someone having been in Miss ANDERSON's room, he says he looked over his own things and found two boxes of White-Bang .22 cartridges missing. (Shots). The value of these cartridges is $5.00 apiece, a total of $10. Eric said he could not be sure they were taken Saturday night, but they were there a couple of days previously, and when he looked for them Sunday, they were gone. This boy was then asked whether he had seen any Indians around the school or down town in Birtle on Saturday, who might have been responsible. He replied that he did see one fellow that he thought was from the Rosebud Reserve (Lizard Point), but he did not know his name, being from Rolling River himself. This man was rather drunk, and he was wearing a red and white hockey sweater with the number "11" on the back. When Eric saw this man, he was on the main street of the town of Birtle, and was all alone.

Other inquiries in and around the town of Birtle failed to reveal anyone who knew this allegedly drunk Indian, although several persons stated they remembered seeing him around. The only description was that he was a medium-sized Indian, very dark, and wearing a sweater with the number "11" on the back. As far as could be learned, this was the only Indian noticed in town on Saturday night.

The Principal, Mr. ZOBEN, occupies a suite of rooms on the main floor of the building, and the engineer, Fred FINDLAY, has a room in the basement. Mr. HUGAN could not be interviewed this date as he was away to a Reservation in Saskatchewan for a load of children to start the fall term. Fred FINDLAY could offer no information of value. He stated he was in bed before midnight Saturday, and he heard nothing whatever until time to get up Sunday morning. He could suggest no possible suspects at all, having seen nobody loitering around the school recently whatever. He said the children sleeping in the school just now could be entirely trusted, and the theft must have been committed by an outsider.

Miss Fay ANDERSON was next questioned, and she told of being awakened about 4:00 a.m. Sunday, and seeing a big Indian standing in her room by her bed. She was badly frightened, and screamed frantically. The Indian turned and ran, and there was just sufficient light for her to say that he was wearing a red and tan two-tone sweater, similar to a hockey sweater, with a spot on the back which could have been a number. She was so frightened that she only took time to slam her door shut and then she jumped back into bed and stayed there until morning.

The little girls sleeping in the dormitory at the West end of the corridor stated they did not hear anything during the night at all. They are only young children, about eight and nine years, respectively, and all members of the school staff state that they are beyond suspicion.

Eric SHORTING, who sleeps at the East end of the corridor, was next interviewed. He was questioned at some length, but could give no definite information. He said he heard nothing at all during the night in question, but slept soundly until morning. When he heard of the money being stolen from Miss HAUGEN, and of someone having been in Miss ANDERSON's room, he says he looked over his own things and found two boxes of Whiz-Bang .22 cartridges missing (shorts). The value of these cartridges is 25¢ apiece, a total of 50¢. Eric said he could not be sure they were taken Saturday night, but they were there a couple of days previously, and when he looked for them Sunday, they were gone. This boy was then asked whether he had seen any Indians around the school or down town in Birtle on Saturday, who might have been responsible. He replied that he did see one fellow that he thought was from the Roseburn Reserve (Lizard Point), but he did not know his name, being from Rolling River himself. This man was rather drunk, and he was wearing a red and white hockey sweater with the number "11" on the back. When Eric saw this man, he was on the main street of the town of Birtle, and was all alone.

Other inquiries in and around the town of Birtle failed to reveal anyone who knew this allegedly drunk Indian, although several persons stated they remembered seeing him around. The only description was that he was a medium-sized Indian, very dark, and wearing a sweater with the number "11" on the back. As far as could be learned, this was the only Indian noticed in town on Saturday night.

(See page 3)
The following day, 23-8-46, patrol was made by the writer and Capt. DAVIDSON to the Lizard Point Indian Reservation. Mr. A.G. SMITH, Indian Agent, was on the reserve this date, and the matter was discussed with him and with Mr. HENRY HILL, the farm instructor. The possibilities of some member of this farm having committed the offense was considered, particularly those Indians known to have hockey sweaters. After a full discussion of the matter, the name of Godfrey MARSHALL, Godfrey MARSHALL, was suggested as the most likely suspect. This man has rather a poor reputation, and he was known to have a hockey sweater, although the number of it was not known.

Patrol continued to Rossburn, and the R.C.O. I/C Rossburn detachment was contacted in an effort to locate MARSHALL. Inquiries continued for some time around Rossburn, and patrol then returned to Russell.

The following day, 24-8-46, OpL MURRAY called this detachment from Rossburn with the information that MARSHALL had heard the police were looking for him, so had presented himself at the Rossburn detachment office. He told MARSHALL that it was the Russell police who were looking for him, and MARSHALL thereupon stated he would go to Russell and find out what was wrong.

About 5:00 p.m., this date, Godfrey MARSHALL called at this office. He was wearing his hockey sweater, bearing the number "11" on the back. He was thoroughly interrogated regarding his movements in Birtle last Saturday night, but he denied all knowledge of the theft. He did admit being drunk in Birtle, but he says he went up the hill to the C.P.R. station and went to sleep there, and he did not remember being asleep near the school. He said he had only a couple of dollars in his pocket when he went to sleep, and when he woke in the morning in the station, he did not have any more, so he said he could not have stolen any and forgotten it. He did not go down town again on Sunday morning, but got on the train for Churchbridge, Saskatoon, and from there went on to Rossburn looking for work. He returned to Rossburn Monday night and heard the police were looking for him on Tuesday night, so came on in to see what was the matter.

Subject then volunteered to accompany the writer to Birtle for the purpose of confronting any witnesses, and so settling once and for all, whether he was the one who stole the money. Patrol was made forthwith, and interrogation was continued all the way to Birtle, without result.

When in Birtle, various witnesses were contacted downtown, and they stated this was the man who was drunk downtown on Saturday night. (See Sep. report this date under the heading of "Godfrey MARSHALL, Non-Treaty Indian, Rossburn Man, Intoxication, Section 135, The Indian Act"). Miss ANDERSON, however, at the Indian School, could not identify subject, and even said he did not appear quite as big a man as the one she saw in her room. She admitted, however, that he might be bigger to her than he was, under the circumstances, she could not identify him.
The Principal of the school, Mr. M.M. Moran, was also interviewed this date. He could not offer any information that would point suspicion at any particular person, but he did recall seeing an Indian walking East on the railway track on Sunday morning. He said it would be fairly early, around 6:00 a.m., or so, before he heard of the theft from Miss Haugh. He did not get a good look at the man, but he seemed to be wearing a red sweater under a top coat, and looked like a fairly good sized man.

16. The Indian Agent, Mr. A.G. Smith, was again visited this date. He mentioned the name of another possible suspect, James Keewatinappo @ McQuaide. He said the last he heard of this Indian, he had gone to the Selagirth district, looking for work. Keewatinappo also wears a hockey sweater, and he is a fairly big Indian. In addition he has a rather poor reputation, and he attended the Birtle Indian School a couple of years ago, so would know his way around the building and would therefore be a very likely suspect. It could have been Keewatinappo that Mr. Moran noticed walking East along the track on Sunday morning, as Selagirth is just eight miles North-East of Birtle.

17. Other inquiries this date failed to reveal any more definite information, and the whereabouts of James Keewatinappo could not be ascertained. Further patrols will be made whenever possible, and efforts made to locate this Indian and have him questioned. Mr. Smith has also promised to try and find out about it and notify this office as soon as he learns anything of value.

1. With reference to the above, and further to the marginally-noted I have to report that no more information of any kind has come to hand. Inquiries have continued with all diligence; the complainant has been kept in touch with and various reliable contacts have been watching for any possible scraps of information, but without result.

2. This offence, it will be remembered, occurred in the early a.m. of Sunday, August 25th, 1946. Someone, presumably an Indian, entered the Indian Residential School at Birtle, Manitoba, and wandered into a room where Miss Judith HAUGEN, a member of the staff, was sleeping. He stole a small change purse containing about $7.00 in unidentifiable cash. He then walked into an adjoining room, but the occupant, Miss Fay ANDERSON, awakened and frightened him away by screaming. The matter was reported by letter received here on August 27th, and inquiries were commenced forthwith. Various Indians of this and the Rossturn district, all possible suspects, were carefully interrogated, and were eliminated as far as possible. Inquiries have continued unabated since that time, but nothing whatever of value has been learned. It seems that all possible avenues of investigation have been fully covered, and there is now small chance of successfully concluding the case. The only thing stolen was a small change purse, which would no doubt be promptly thrown away, after removing the seven dollars cash which it contained.

3. The complainant states that she appreciates the efforts which have been spent on the matter, but she does not consider it of any use to continue investigation any longer, particularly since there was nothing stolen which could be identified. The writer is in full agreement with the complainant's attitude, and in view of the facts of this case, as set out above, may we please be advised whether it will be in order to refer the file to the Crown Attorney, N.J.D., for his opinion as to closing it out.

ADVISE BY WIRE IF LIVING QUARTERS PRINCIPAL BIRTLE SCHOOL ARE IN MAIN BUILDING OR IS THERE SEPARATE PRINCIPAL'S RESIDENCE

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Charge: Indian Affairs.
The Presbyterian Church in Canada began its mission amongst the Indians in 1866 near the present site of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. An extensive work was begun on several reserves and churches and schools were built.

When church union was consummated in 1925 a part of this task was undertaken by the United Church in Canada.

At the present time besides the work on the reserves we have two residential schools and one improved day school under the care of our Church - Birtle School, Manitoba; Cecilia Jeffrey School, Kenora, Ontario; and Mistawasis School, near Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

**BIRTLE SCHOOL**

119 pupils enrolled, 63 girls and 56 boys, from the following reserves:

- Mistawasis 25
- Round Plains (near Prince Albert) 4
- Rolling River 11
- Elphinstone 14
- Griswold 6
- Valley River 1
- Birdtail 15
- Waywayseecappo 43

In the Birtle School the course of study as outlined by the Department of Education for Manitoba is followed and all subjects listed therein are taught. All grades attend for the full school-day period from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. as in the Provincial schools. With the full-day system almost all children are able to cover the work outlined in the course for the year in that time. Four pupils are doing two grades in the one year. The highest grade is grade eight. Some pupils have
voluntarily expressed their desire to return for further education but whether they will or not is yet to be known. In the great majority of cases the parents persuade them to stay home.

**Special Subjects:**

Household Science, which covers all phases of sewing and cooking, is taught to all girls over nine years of age. The four-year course outlined by The Extension Service Branch of the Department of Agriculture for Manitoba is followed. Each group receives one-half day per week of instruction and work and one evening per week. Near the conclusion of the term an Achievement Day is held in the school and all the work is displayed. The public is invited to the display and the articles are judged by a representative from the Extension Branch. Also articles are prepared for entry in the Indian Classes at the Brandon Exhibition.

The boys in grades 3 to 8, inclusive, spend one-half day per week and one evening in Manual Training. This is the first year that a full course has been given in this work. As yet the workshop is too small and only hand tools are available, which limit the type and kind of work being done.

The girls and boys take a keen interest in both Household Science and Manual Training, and spend a great deal of their spare time on this.

Grades 3 to 8 each have two half-hour periods of physical training per week. Some of the classes are held in the auditorium and the others in the playrooms. In the warm weather they are held outside. Boys and girls are taken
separately, and the period is spent in teaching folk dances, tumbling, physical exercises and organized games.

The nurse has taken health classes with all grades each week through the term. The senior girls are completing a course in Home Nursing and the senior boys a course in First Aid. These are the courses outlined by the St. John's Ambulance Corps and the students are writing the examination as set by this organization. The representative of the Corps will be visiting the school before the end of the term to test the students in the work covered.

Some vocal music is taught in each classroom by the teacher in charge. The children are very fond of singing. Six boys take violin lesson and there is a very good violin orchestra. They practise for fifteen minutes every day at noon. Twelve girls are taking piano lessons. Some from each reserve are selected; and each practises for half an hour a day.

Staff:

At present we have thirteen staff members. We hope to have a full staff by the beginning of September. The members of the staff are all very co-operative and there are some outstanding leaders among them. They take a very keen interest in the school and its progress, get along with the children exceptionally well and work together harmoniously.

Children's Transportation:

The children from the Birdtail Reserve are brought to and from the school by their parents, and the cost of transportation of the children from all the other reserves is borne by the school.
The biggest item of transportation is the cost of bringing in the children from the Mistawasis and Round Plains Reserves. They are taken part way by train and the rest of the way by truck. This amounts to a considerable sum each year. Each year the Department allows our Society a grant to cover part of the cost.

Sports:

Winter time is the real sport season for these children. The juniors enjoy sleigh-riding on the hills in front of the school. They have a number of hand-sleighs which were in constant use all winter. The rink was most popular with the seniors. Every boy had a pair of skates, as well as all the senior and intermediate girls who wished them. Every day all winter they were out either on the hill or on the rink with a supervisor. The boys took a keen interest in hockey and both the Pee-wee and Midget teams were successful in most games with white teams in the district. The Midgets won all matches.

In summer some football and softball are played. The little girls enjoy the swings but should have a few more. The little boys play a great deal in the bush near the school.

All the children look forward to a party each month. The juniors have their party from seven to nine in the evening which consists of games, supervised by one of the staff, followed by lunch. The seniors' parties usually start as soon as the juniors have left the auditorium for lunch. Theirs consist of contests, games, stunts and some dancing.

June brings the annual picnic and sports days each year.
Every Thursday evening a moving picture is shown in the auditorium. One teacher has qualified as an operator of 16 mm. projectors. Films are obtained from the National Film Board free of charge and a number from the Visual Education Branch of the Department of Education. These are both instructive and entertaining.

Farm:

The Principal and Farm Manager strive to have the very finest of animals on the farm and the herd of cows is fully accredited. It is one of the best Dual Purpose herds in Manitoba.

The farm, including a quarter section owned by the Church, consists of approximately 880 acres. A great deal of it is waste land and much of it is hilly, rocky and slough. There are about 125 acres of arable land on the Church quarter and about 200 on the school property.

Most of the produce of the farm is used at the school.

Dear Sir:

I am writing to acknowledge your letter of August 25th re the Birtle School. We are interested to know that Major C.A.F. Clark intends to visit the School in September. Would you be kind enough to send me the approximate date of his visit? My reason for asking this is that there is a possibility that I shall be going to Birtle either in September or October.

The letter you enclosed from Mr. Smith came as rather a surprise to us, although we had had a letter from our missionary on the reserve near Rossburn telling us of certain dissatisfaction amongst the Indians. The chief complaint seemed to be that Mr. Rusaw smoked a pipe before the children. The missionary was of the opinion that an ordained minister should be appointed as Principal. The problem at the present time when there are so many preaching places vacant would be to find a minister suited for this type of work. In concluding his letter the missionary said, "Personally I have no fault to find with our School or its staff".

During this summer we have had some members of the Birtle staff visit us here in the office. They spoke very highly of Mr. Rusaw and of his tireless efforts to improve the school. You will also be interested to know that Miss Kenny, former senior class room teacher, is returning after a year's absence to resume her teaching at Birtle. Her work was of the best and I think that it speaks well for Mr. Rusaw when Miss Kenny is willing to become a member of the teaching staff again.

Having been on the staff of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, Kenora, some years ago and knowing something of the Indian characteristics, my sympathy is with Mr. Rusaw in his problem of keeping the Indians from loitering about the school. On the other hand, we have to remember that the present system of taking children into the residential schools is perhaps not the solution to the difficulties of the Indian people. The parents quite naturally become lonesome for their children and, having no special responsibilities around their homes on the reserves, they see no reason for not camping as

Mr. Indian Agent Smith and I spent the morning of Tuesday, Sept. 2, going over and discussing the school and school matters with the Principal.

October 22, 1947.

To the Parents of our Pupils:

I feel certain you will be happy to learn that the school has settled down for another successful year. Most of last year's pupils are back with the exception of the graduates and a few whose parents do not seem to care whether their children obtain a fair chance to receive an education.

We have welcomed sixteen new pupils. Three of the older pupils have been admitted to the senior classes from other schools to take advantage of the high grade facilities we have here. One of our students is taking work in the high school in the City of Birtle with the object of obtaining his matriculation standing. If he does so, it will enable him to study for a profession if he so desires. It is hoped that more will take advantage of the same opportunity as they may become future doctors, nurses and teachers so urgently required on many of our reserves.

All the children are well and you may be assured that if your child is seriously ill at any time you will be notified promptly.

Our Hallowe'en party will be held on Friday evening, October 31st and we invite you to attend this party and spend Saturday and Sunday regular visiting hours with the children.

As you already know, we have no regular accommodation for visiting parents who wish to spend the night at the school. Therefore, we ask your co-operation by not asking for more than previously.

Visiting rules are the same as last year, namely Saturday afternoons and evenings until 10 p.m., and Sunday after Sunday school in the morning until 4:15 in the afternoon.

Some complaints were made last year regarding the condition of the shed where the horses owned by visiting Indians are stabled. This building requires repairs and it has been suggested that the Rosshorn men group together and put in a few hours' work on it when they visit the school at the end of October. May I suggest that you do your share of the work on Saturday morning and make it more comfortable for your horses. I will endeavour to have materials and tools ready for the job.

Please feel free to write to me at any time and let us all co-operate for the progress and happiness of the children.

Yours truly,

N.M. Rusaw
Principal.

I understand there are now enrolled 105 pupils but the Principal expected this number to be increased shortly to at least 115. The classroom teachers are Mrs. Kenny, Mrs. Deane and Mr. Frost. They all appear greatly interested in the children and are undoubtedly doing good work, especially Mr. Frost and Mrs. Kenny. All teachers are qualified.

The boys' supervisor is Mr. Woolen. He is also the vocational teacher. Mr. Woolen is a young man with a good personality and is well liked by all.

The school throughout was very clean. The dormitories were well aired. The beds neatly made and with ample bedding.

Mrs. McLeod is the kitchen matron. She is a splendid cook and the girls are receiving a good training. I believe the children are well fed.

The outbuildings have recently been painted and are in good repair.

The new root cellar has just been completed and is packed to the roof with potatoes, carrots, beets, cabbages and turnips. The vegetables are of excellent quality. The cellar is dry and cool and the vegetables should keep in excellent condition. This cellar is 16' x 20' x 7' high - I believe ample storage for a school of this size.

The cattle are now stabled. At present 10 cows are being milked. Mr. Rusaw, the Principal, keeps a fair number of hogs and all will be used for food at the school.

Poultry is kept and on the day of my visit 115 eggs had been gathered. Turkeys are also kept but this year hatching conditions were poor and the undertaking practically a failure. A flock of ducks was raised and are doing well. I understand all surplus stock is used as food for the staff and pupils.

The yards about the school were tidy and I was told that the display of flowers in front of the school was admired by all who saw them.

Mr. Rusaw has worked hard and in my opinion operates a school which is a credit to the Department and the Church. Mr. Rusaw appears interested in the children and discipline is no problem.

Extract from a report of the Acting Agent for the Birtle Indian Agency, dated October 12th on the Birtle Indian Residential School.

Birtle Residential School is operating at full capacity, with several changes in the staff. Three pupils attend High School in Birtle in grade nine and one in grade ten. I herewith submit a report on the Birtle Residential School and the Griswold Indian Day School.

Birtle Residential School

The above school was visited on November 9th, and Mr. Rusaw, the Principal, appears to be a very capable man. The school was found very tidy, and the buildings very well cared for; all minor repairs have been taken care of by the Principal. The outbuildings, including the barn and chicken house, are in wonderful condition.

The pupils are getting a very good training in the care of livestock, raising chickens, etc. They are milking 15 cows, and have 300 hens and a few geese and ducks. The chickens are split into bands of 50 and two boys are in charge of each band for a certain period. The hens are laying well, and the school is getting an ample supply.

This school is very well staffed, and all appear to be of a superior type. There are three classrooms - 46 pupils in grades 5 to 8; 40 in grades 2 to 4; 34 in grades 1 to 2. The school is in need of cupboards and tables in the sewing room, as at present they are using makeshift tables and have not any cupboards whatsoever, for taking care of their clothes. Mr. Rusaw advised me that the estimated cost of the work is $400. However, if an amount of $200 could be allowed, the work could be started this year, and completed next year. Tables could be built and a few cupboards put in.

A number of the pupils in this school are from the Mistawasis Band in Saskatchewan, where we have a good day school. No doubt these children are sent to this school owing to fact that the teacher at Mistawasis, Mr. Moore, is not competent. I see no reason why these children cannot stay at home and attend the day school, instead of being sent to Birtle. A number of their homes are close to the school, and from past experience, I know that most of the families would rather have their children at home - if a good teacher is provided.

Griswold Indian Day School - (Oak River)

The teacher, Mrs. Spence, seems very capable. The classroom was in first-class condition, and
the children looked neat and clean. There are 27 pupils on the register and 25 were in class at the time of my visit.

I do not consider the new desks supplied from the penitentiary, are going to be satisfactory. The workmanship seems to be poor and a number of the tops are already broken. They will have to be replaced with heavy plywood, and I have instructed Mr. Young to have this done.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

The Indians of the Waywayseecappo, Rolling River, and Keesekoowenin Bands are very much upset about the dates set for the Christmas holidays for the children attending the Birtle Residential School. They leave school on the 18th inst., and return on January 2nd as January 3rd is a full day in school. They would not mind the children staying in school until the 21st or 22nd inst., and returning on January 3rd or 4th. They have no complaints about the length of the holiday, but as you know, New Years day is the big day for the Indians, and I suppose they have learned this from the Scotch.

To be in school for a full day on the 3rd of January, the children from the Rolling River and Keesekoowenin Reserves, will have to drive by team from 10 to 20 miles on Sunday, wait at a railway depot until about 2 a.m. on Monday morning, take the train for Birtle arriving about 4.30 a.m. The children will certainly not derive any benefit from their classes on Monday after a night like that. The children from the Waywayseecappo Band will have to drive from 24 to 30 miles by team on Sunday, the day after New Years.

The parents were very glad to have the children home for the Christmas season last year, and every one was back to school on time. Knowing the Indians, I feel sure that most of the children will not be back until the 3rd and 4th of January this year. On the 4th there is a good train in the afternoon which the children from Rolling River and Keesekoowenin Bands could take. The parents inform me that the children from Sandy Bay School do not return until January 7th, if that is so it will cause further dissatisfaction. Knowing the circumstances,
I cannot blame the parents for grumbling.

Mr. M. Husaw, the Principal of the School informs me that he requested permission to change the dates to suit local condition, but the Department refused to allow it.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet; paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of quarterly grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE
