NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 20th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging if No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. Sir:

I have the honour to report that I examined the Boarding School building at this place with regard to the efficiency of the appliance at hand and ready for use in event of a fire breaking out, and to report that in my opinion the appliances are inadequate.

The building is of stone, and there are two wide stairways leading from the basement to garret, and although there may not be much likelihood of both these stairways, which are fully twenty feet apart, being on fire at the same time and shutting off the means of escape that one or both would supply to the inmates, yet, for the protection of the building there should be two dozen hand grenades and a dozen water pails scattered through the building, at least.

In the basement there are two hot air furnaces, a cooking range and a box stove.

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, in which you request that a blackboard and a teacher's desk, of the dimensions stated by you, be supplied for the use of the Birtle Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that a hyloplate blackboard, 24' x 4', with the necessary chalk trough and moulding, will be ordered through the Government Stationery Office, to be forwarded to the Principal of the school.

Hyloplate is made of pulp and, necessarily, absorbs a good deal of moisture in wet weather and shrinks in dry weather. Consequently, care should be taken in installing these boards and have them fitted in the frame in such a manner as will permit of expansion.

If at all possible, hyloplate should not be installed close to the stove, as, if so, it is subjected to very great heat which cracks the surface. Water should not be used to clean hyloplate blackboards.

The Department trusts that you will keep these instructions in mind and have the blackboards carefully installed on their arrival. You should also point out to the Principal that water should not be used for cleaning them.

"Re Principal's residence -- I am not prepared to advise. The responsibility of the Principal for 40 Indian girls and 30 Indian boys as regards their morals, discipline, health and safety to say nothing of food and clothing is so great that I would not take the responsibility of the task without living with them, and sleeping within hearing of dormitories at night. To do otherwise would mean that I nominally had the responsibility while someone else had the burden of it. We are practically all on duty all the time.

However, it is almost impossible for an unmarried man to fill the position and equally impossible for a man with a young family to live in the school. Since my girls are 14 and 16 years old, I may be able to do so. I leave this to the discretion of your Board.

Do we need to enlarge the School? We have sixty-seven on our roll now and I have a list of children who are a little over six years on these reserves before me numbering 25 in all. They will get no education till we bring them in here and we certainly have no room for them under present conditions. We have had, since holidays, 10 cases of mumps and 3 cases of erysipelas and it is most difficult to isolate these. If we put them out in a cottage we would have to stay with them and this would require a couple more on the staff. Consequently, it has made a lot of extra work. We require a nurses' room and a sick room for girls and one for boys. Besides our dormitories and classrooms are already crowded.

I have made a rough draft of an extension. It is difficult to get estimates until a definite plan is made and this would cost too much unless we had something definite that we proposed to build. These sketches fill in the hollow square at the back of the building and would give an extension 49 x 33 or better still we could extend the length to 60 ft. x 33.

The advantages of this would be that we would have only two outside walls to build - the roof would be flat - no front entrance to build, no interior stairs - is as close to our present heating system as any other part of the building - would not necessitate any change of our present sewer system - and would not interfere with the work of the school while in process of erection.

This would give us just about what we need and I think at the least possible cost. At present I could only make a guess at what it would cost but think it should be built and completed for between six and seven thousand dollars.

While I have stated the needs and the best way of doing it and the probable cost you must consider these as only suggestions on my part. I do not want to assume responsibility of advocating or urging any of these.

I will do my best to carry out the wishes and plans of any who may have charge of this work."

She was a stretcher patient and we rode in the baggage car with her. We went at great inconvenience to ourselves and left our work and rode on the train two nights without sleep to save expense. We made no charge for our time. I have been out of this $74.25 (part) since last Aug. It's no part of our work to do this kind of thing except as we do it for charity sake. If you do not want to pay the actual outlay in a reasonable time you had better do it through the agent and pay what it is worth.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In our Indian School work, we recognize that the farm is a part of the School, and that the practical training in the different branches of farming, is an important part of our teaching. We feel that we are not equipped for this part of our work as we should be; our horses, harness, and machinery are getting old and worn out, and should be replaced with new ones.

We require this Spring, a team of heavy horses, a set of heavy harness, a cultivator, a seed drill, a walking plow, grain binder, and mower. We are handicapped in our work as compared with schools that have Government owned equipment.

In our annual report to the Department this year the Church had contributed over $7000.00 to the support of this school for the year, for salaries, clothing etc., in addition to what the Government had paid, and the farm produced.

As we require other improvements to buildings fences, and stock, we feel that we can hardly ask the church to buy this part of the equipment that we require.

We sincerely hope that the Indian Department may be able to help us out, in purchasing this farm equipment for us.

As I am not well enough to come to your office, am sending on a few lines for your consideration re our Birtle L. B. S. Mr. Pitts, is feeling keenly that this work has been held up by dept. as he has over 70 children in residence now with 25 more ready to come in - one hundred pupils for Birtle without any trouble.

I have considered the matter over carefully and do not think that union between the two churches should make any difference between Birtle and Portage for each could guarantee at least 100 pupils which would give them industrial standing. Both are situated most favorably to carry on separately and become industrial. If present improvements could be carried out at Birtle so that the School could be ready for Aug. 1st, 1924, there is nothing to stand in the way of our bringing Portage and Birtle up to Government Standard. Even now I claim we are industrial in all but name and extra grant and have ascertained that schools, not any larger, in other denominations, are receiving Industrial grants. We should have two schools in Manitoba - as our largest Indian work lies there - then our C. J. - this is in Northern Ontario - could be moved to a district in the Lake of the Woods perhaps near to Kewadyro. We could easily have 150 pupils here at a point near to the railway location to be decided by Church and Govt. Now, what I wish you would do right now, is to ask the Dept. to go on with Birtle repairs, putting the foundation this fall and completing the job next spring, so that the school would be ready for 100 pupils next Aug. Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 10th inst. No. 106-1-5, informing me that you had been discussing with the Presbyterian Church authorities the advisability of providing more accommodation at the Birtle Indian School.

I note that it is your intention to make a grant of $2000 for alterations and addition to the main building. You have left entirely to the Church authorities the matter of the spending of this $2000. I do not think this is safeguarding the interests of the Department; however it is not for me to criticize.

I do not think it is fair to ask me to be responsible for a building program in the West, and then tell me I can hand the work over to our Indian Agents and Principals of Schools. This is, to my mind, unreasonable, and it is just the opposite of my understanding with the Department, when in Ottawa.

I am now preparing a report, which shows that over $50,000 was actually wasted at Elkhorn, through carrying on work in this manner. There was a deliberate waste, tearing down construction that should never have been touched; ripping up floors which were in perfectly good repair; replacing engines which would not have been replaced. All of which is accounted for by the fact that the man in charge of the work was getting ten percent on material and labor. If we are going to continue work in this way, we might as well cancel all arrangements that were made while I was in Ottawa. I will not take responsibility for the building program, if the Department say who I am to delegate this work to.

Yours very truly,

D. C. Scott, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

Yours of 24th inst. to hand. I note its contents and the underlying rebuff at my interfering with the building operations. Please note that in Dep. Supt. Gen. Scott's letter to you of May 10th he asked that the Agent and I oversee the building of the school rooms.

I regret that I am in a position where I need to point out to you the absolute impossibility of the school rooms you are building. I am aware that the Ottawa offices have approved your plans and that you have taken them from the Manitoba Provincial plans. I have taken considerable time to study out why any architect would use such a ventilating system. When I got your letter of above date I saw at once where the mistake was likely made. You have taken an architect's plan for a one room school with windows on opposite sides and as you state in your letter have doubled it, thus making rooms with windows on only one side. This leaves no draught of air across the room. Even with the farthest window open the draught between that and the ventilating flue leaves more than half of the room (diagonally) untouched.

The specifications call for balanced sashes, but the bill of material made no provision for sash cords and weights and I understand you have refused to put these in, which very much increases the difficulty of ventilation.

I cannot be responsible for putting the pupils or teachers in these rooms unless you ventilate properly. If you do not care to look into the matter now while they are being built I will submit the plans to the Inspector at Ottawa.

I wish to point out in this connection that two years ago you wrote me that our number of pupils allowed was cut down from 75 to 70 and afterwards to 65 because of the overcrowded condition of the class-rooms and dormitories.

above that were easily worked, both the top and bottom sashes had pulleys and balanced weights. Besides we had the ventilating flues in the chimney.

Our reasons for asking the Department to help us enlarge was first that our number should not be cut down and secondly that we should be able to take in 100 pupils.

You have all the facts as I see them. I am acting in the interest of the school and I expect you to treat it accordingly.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I have gone carefully into the plans and specifications for this school of two rooms also the correspondence and fail to understand the criticism from your correspondent at Birtle, dated July the 28th, 1924.

The design in every way is a standard type, evolved after some twenty years experience here, spent in planning and equipping school buildings, under western conditions.

The size and cubic contents of each room, the lighting, heating, ventilation, details of elevation and equipment are in close conformity to regulation and in consequence are absolutely authoritative.

The building was designed by me for a two room school and not adapted from a one room school as suggested, and the only change made was to substitute basement furnace heating instead of the original stove heating in classrooms, which I consider an improvement.

An air space of 21456 cubic feet for two class rooms referred to in your correspondent's letter is wasteful, not only on construction cost but in annual expenditure for winter heating. For the same reason any change in the size of ventilation flue shown would undoubtedly be detrimental as same is accurately proportioned to move a certain quantity of air at a given velocity at a certain temperature condition, both interior and exterior of the building. The windows are intended to open fully at top and bottom by opening sashes, balanced by weights or spring balances - either would meet with my approval, the latter having the advantage of tighter and therefore warmer construction in wintry weather.

I do not propose at this stage to go closely into the details involved or reasons why—for instance—the room is 22.6 wide, no more and no less—or why the vent and smoke flues are 12x12 or 13x13 (brick and half) and so on ad infinitum, but I do take here and now strong exception to such a line of unreasonable criticism as has been displayed in this instance.
Your correspondent would be well advised to acquire some knowledge of a highly technical and specialized subject before taking the responsibility of committing his criticism to the written word.

Yours very truly,

J. H. Curtin

Dear Sir:

With regard to the present air space provided you seem to be unnecessarily alarmed. There is an air space of 6,750 cubic feet in each room. This provides for a pupilage of 90 with two class-rooms, and if we are to have the half-day system you have air space capacity for 180 children, and as you are not likely to ever have more than 100 children present you have more class-room space than you will ever use. REGINA, SASK., August 1st, 1924

Dear Mr. Pitts,

I am enclosing herewith for your personal perusal a letter that I have received from Mr. Pitts, Principal of the Birtle Boarding School.

I have no desire to be drawn into any controversy with Mr. Pitts or Dr. Edmonson of Toronto over this matter, but you will see from the letter that Mr. Pitts is displeased at not being given charge of the work at the Birtle School.

In the first place I did not think he was capable of undertaking this work and in the second place I do not see how I could be held responsible for the work if I did not have the privilege of engaging what, in my opinion, was a proper man. As there was no comparison between the qualifications of Mr. Lazenby and Mr. Pitts, and you know as well as I do that two men cannot boss one job, I put the work in the hands of the proper party, viz:- our own officer.

In reading Mr. Pitts' letter you would think that the plans that I sent to him were far from being what they should. On the contrary, the School Plans were the very latest and most up-to-date. The ventilation system is in accordance with the Provincial Government regulations. The windows are hung with fixtures the same as are used on all modern school buildings. The air space provides for a pupilage at one time of 90, or in other words allowing that only one third are absent at other occupations it would provide for a school of 120. If we adopt the half-day system it would provide for 180 children, still he thinks that he is cramped for room.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Mr. Pitts says that I had correspondence with him, recommending a reduction of the pupilage in the school from 75 to 65 on account of inadequate air space in the class-rooms. This is not true. If he has 21456 cubic feet of air in his class-rooms he has room for 140 children; this is more than he ever will have so that I think he is mistaken in this. He may have had a letter from the Department about reducing the pupilage, but it was not on the ground of over-crowding of the class-rooms.

With regard to his complaint about the ventilating system. This is modern and adequate in every way and there is no ground for complaint here.

Now, Mr. Scott, I think it is unfair that this man should write to me a letter such as he has. He undoubtedly will take this matter up with Dr. Edmison. I have been led into this thing quite innocently. He is sore because the work has been handled as it has and I do not think that a matter of this kind should be passed over. I think a severe reprimand is coming to Mr. Pitts from the Department.

I took the trouble after getting Mr. Pitts' letter to consult with Mr. Punton, Architect of the Regina Public School Board, and I am enclosing herewith a copy of his letter for your guidance. I would be glad if action could be taken to straighten this matter out because it is only going to grow from one thing to another if something is not done.

I am enclosing two letters which I have written to Mr. Pitts so that you will have the correspondence before you to date.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your No. 201-11A of the 8th instant, with reference to the Birtle Indian Residential School. In reply I have to inform you that in 1922 I had some correspondence with Dr. Edmison, regarding the crowded conditions at the school. Upon the assurance of the Doctor that the principal had provided more dormitory space, it was decided not to reduce the pupilage from 75. A few weeks after this decision had been reached, following a report from the medical officer for the school, the question was again raised and it was found that there was a total of 29,620 cubic feet of air space in the three girls' and two boys' dormitories. This indicated that the pupilage should be limited to 60. The average attendance for the September and December quarters of that year was 60.3 and 61.5. In 1923, when the average attendance increased somewhat, no action was taken, as the question of providing more accommodation was being favourably considered.

Unfortunately, the unsatisfactory classroom condition was coupled with the question of the overcrowded dormitory. Mr. Ferrier, in his report in 1922, drew attention to the fact that there were too many pupils in the classroom and that a second room and teacher were necessary, unless the half-day system was to be adopted. His criticism was based upon the fact that there were too many pupils for one teacher and not upon the air space provided.

You may inform Mr. Pitts that the Department considers two classrooms, accommodating 30 pupils each, are sufficient in the case of a residential school with a pupilage of 90.

Yours very truly,

MEMO FOR FILE:

I visited the Birtle Indian Residential School on July 7th, and as there were no pupils in residence, my impressions were confined to the management, buildings and farm. The Principal is, I believe, a good all-round man and he has a splendid wife. He appeared to be more of an idealist than a practical type. The farm is 3 miles away and is not very productive and the garden at the school has not been of great value. The grounds were not in very good shape. More outbuildings are needed and also some agricultural machinery. There was some talk of applying for a filter for the water supply, but I advised the Principal to have the water analyzed first.

The alterations to the main building were nicely started and they were excavating for the new classroom building.

Sir:

A short time ago I received a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Indian Residential School at Birtle with reference to the re-decorating of the interior of that institution arising out of the report of Travelling Nurse, Miss A.G. Brandon, who was at the school in June last.

I visited this school about two years ago and noted how dull the interior was on account of the color and character of the paint used, and it was the intention at that time to insert an item in the Estimates providing for material for re-decorating. This was not done either that year or the following year, and the same conditions still prevail.

Figures showing the surface to be covered indicate that the cost of the material required will approximate $200.00, and if the Department will consent to provide this amount I would recommend it, but the Church authorities should undertake to bear the cost of the labor.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir,

Re Water Tank in Indian School.

I beg to submit the following Report as requested by Rev. R. Paterson.

This tank is said to contain 1600 to 1800 gallons of water and will weigh 8 to 9 tons. The tank is located above the roof and is supported on 4x6 in. posts at 5 ft. centers extending down to and resting on the flooring of the upper floor. The joists of this floor are carried by two 2x4 in. stud partitions 3' 6" apart through First and Second stories and resting on the First floor joists. This floor is carried by a beam in the Basement which rests on one wooden post and a very defective concrete wall. The posts carrying the tank do not rest on the partitions but the load is carried to the partitions by the top floor joists.

Where posts rest on flooring there is a settlement of nearly 2 inches and this settlement continues to Ground floor and doors in partitions are badly out of square.

The post in Basement has rotted entirely away from its bearing on the footing and does not in any manner support the Basement beam under floor joists, the entire load of floors and tank being taken by this defective concrete wall.

I have already instructed you that this post should be made good at once by cutting off the decayed portion and replacing this with a solid end wood block on stone footing, care being taken to provide strong temporary support under floor when doing this work to prevent any accident as I do not consider this wall safe.

An alternative would be to put in an entirely new post.

I would also recommend that the 6x6 in. posts carrying tank be continued through to basement to take the entire load of the tank off the floors and partitions. These should be continuous and be strongly braced at joints in floors.

I do not consider it would be advisable to attempt to raise the floors to level them as it would without doubt break or loosen the plaster and probably create more trouble than would be justified. The doors could be taken out and made square with little trouble.

I trust the above will be clear to you and if I can be of any service to you please advise me.

Yours Truly,

W.H. Shillinglaw

Inspector Hamilton's Report on Birtle Residential School.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honor to report as follows on the Indian Residential School at Birtle, inspected by me on May 31st, 1927.

Since my last visit to this school, the management has been taken over by the continuing Presbyterian Church and a new principal, Mr. Currie, has been installed. Mr. Currie had just arrived one week before my inspection, with the result that as yet little change had been made.

In my last report, I described the school fully, so will not go into details. However, I feel something should be done to improve conditions in the boys' basement, which is used as a playroom. The ceilings are very low and the walls are badly broken, also the cement on the floors, in fact, the whole place presents a very dilapidated appearance. The entrance to the toilets open off this playroom and the whole place has a very offensive odor. The girls' basement is little better.

The laundry work is done in another part of the basement, and adjacent are rooms at one time used as toilets. From these also there is a slight odor, although Chloride of Lime is used extensively. The laundry is small and very cramped. All the work for about 100 people is done by hand, there being no power machinery of any kind. Miss Muir is in charge of this department and does very good work in spite of her handicap for room and Indian Commissioner.

REGINA.
Inspector Hamilton's Report on Birtle Residential School.

Miss Ferguson is in charge of the kitchen, which is in fairly good condition and well lighted. I doubt if she has given this work much consideration, but I believe this department will improve with the new principal and matron in charge, as they are giving close supervision of what food is provided and the manner in which it is being served.

Miss Otten is the sewing teacher, and the work appeared to be carried on quite satisfactorily. The girls were busy mending and the discipline was good.

Mrs. Currie is now matron and, I believe, found things in a very untidy condition, in fact, she claimed the place was dirty. I saw some of the medicine cupboards, as they were left, and must say that they were certainly far from being clean. Apparently Mr. & Mrs. Pitts let things slide very badly before leaving.

The senior class-room was in charge of Miss Bradly. This work had been carried on by Miss Fleming, but on account of sickness, she was obliged to resign. Miss Bradly is not sure of remaining longer than the holidays. She has only been there since April 1st, but, I believe, is a good teacher and would make a success should she remain. This term's work has been badly interrupted and I feel little progress made. The children were clean and tidy, and the class-room well ventilated and clean. There are 17 boys and 27 girls on the roll.

Miss Thorp is the junior teacher. She is doing good work and I regret to say, she informed me she would be leaving at the end of June. Miss Thorp is an exceptionally good junior teacher, and any school would be fortunate in securing her. The pupils are quite responsive.

The floors in the stone part of the school have sunk a little, due, partly at least, to the arrangement of the water tank in the tower. This is a difficult matter to remedy, but, I understand, is being reported on by the Agent.

Hon. Sirs,

I wrote you the last week of May, shortly after my arrival at Birtle, re the first impressions that I had of Birtle School. Time has only confirmed those impressions. Today with some little experience I can say it is nothing short of criminal to maintain pupils amid such surroundings. Conditions must be improved immediately, or the school should be closed. If the Provincial and Dominion Health Departments were familiar with conditions, I am very sure drastic action would be taken. Three pupils have died in the past six months. And fifty % of the pupils were in need of medical treatment when I arrived in May. Four pupils are still in hospital, three are on the Reserves on sick leave, (six of the above I have not seen yet). If I can correctly read records, this condition is not a new one, and very largely, someone is responsible.

I am most ready to co-operate with the Department in changing the conditions and removing as far as possible the causes of so much illness and deaths.

With this in view I venture to offer the following suggestions. First a new School is what should be provided. But in the meantime the following should receive immediate attention,
1. The Filter Tank. The filter tank is not properly working, the trap in chamber two is off completely, and the stench from the tank comes up the waste pipes and fouls the air in the residence, indicating the traps on the waste or soil pipes is defective. Another cause of foul air in the residence is that every toilet in the school ventilates right into the living rooms.

2. The Laundry. All the laundry work is done in the basement where no sunlight ever penetrates, and very little fresh air. The room itself is small, low ceiling, dark, all the work is done by hand, to do the work under such conditions the laundry is in constant use, and no girl living can day after day work in such surroundings and be healthy.

3. The Heating Plant. The furnaces are old, out of repair and while may have performed the work satisfactory, that they were originally intended to do, the school has since been so much added to that at present they are quite inadequate. The present winter cannot be faced with the furnaces as they are. First they are not safe. Some time ago a fire was started, the steam gauges are gone, and there is no means to indicate what steam pressure you are operating under. And in a fifty degrees of frost temperature, one is very liable to push the furnace, even beyond its endurance, especially when circulation is poor and the residence is not...
comfortable. Last winter five cars of coal was consumed and several extra tons were secured, beside much wood. In spite of the fuel consumption, the building could not be kept comfortable, so I am informed. If a new heating plant is not installed this one should be thoroughly overhauled. With the nature of the water we use I believe the piping must be corroded to such an extent that circulation is almost impossible. This phase of the work cannot be neglected nor even delayed. And while on the subject of heating perhaps at this point will be the best place to say provision should be made for a supply of hot water. All the Laundry water is heated on a kitchen stove in the laundry room. And there is not hot water in a bath room in the school. Every bit of hot water required for bathing 90 pupils and the Staff has to be carried from the kitchen up to the bath rooms, up one or two flights of stairs, in buckets.

4. Drinking Water,

The only water available is pumped up from the Birdtail River. It is a dark dirty water, the drainage from the whole country side, dead animals occasionally come floatation down, they get held up on a bar or brush and decay in the river polluting the water. And in our own particular case, all the drainage from our own filter tank drains into the river, and five hundred yards or less, down the river is the intake where our domestic supply is pumped up from. This we use for drinking cooking and all purposes.
I am sure there are many sources of supply, where good water might be had with a reasonable outlay, I am ready to point out the source when you are ready to consider the matter.

The only place the boys have for play or shelter, when not in school or at work, is a basement room 24 by 18 feet seven foot ceiling, opening off the furnace room on one side and a toilet on the other side. This room the Sun never shines in, and there is no provision for ventilation, the two small windows and door must be kept shut in zero weather to keep your water system from freezing. The wonder is not that 50% of the pupils are sick, rather that 50% are well. Boys cannot be good, and cannot be well, herded like stock, and positively my stock in Alberni had better quarters than my pupils have here.

There is carpentry repairs, painting and kalsomining and what not to be done. But I do want immediate action taken on the five major matters above outlined. Our Gas light certain winter months runs to $65.00. I do not consider it a safe light where children are. Lighting matches continually, putting lights on, and the danger of gas not properly turned off and leaking into the room, A lot of money can be spent here and when you are finished you only have a makeshift. A new school is the only wise move, and if you will promise it for to be started.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith a letter addressed to the Department, written by Mr H.B. Currie, Principal of the Birtle Indian Residential School. Mr Currie brought this letter to me last night, and asked me to transmit it to the Department with any other comment I might make personally regarding its contents.

With regard to the residential building; it is, and has been in the past, my contention that it is practically impossible to keep children healthy, while living in it. There is not a toilet in the building that has a window in it, nor any other means of ventilation; entrance to those on the upper floors is directly from the dormitories, and there is always a peculiar, musty odor in the building.

To Mr Currie's remarks concerning the Filter Tank, and the Laundry, I have nothing to add, as he has covered these matters very well.

Regarding Mr Currie's statements under the heading of "The heating plant", it will be noted that he says that the steam gauges are gone. These however were on the boilers last winter, and were in operation. Where they have gone to, I am at a loss to know. Mr Currie also mentions that "a fire was started some time ago"; this fire, however was not started from the furnaces. The fire occurred on February 4th 1925, and in this connection I beg to refer you to my letter to the Department, No; 15 dated 13th February 1925; Departmental letter No; 106-1-1 dated 13th February 1925, and my reply thereto No; 15 dated 17th February 1925. Since the school building was added to in the summer of 1924, the present furnaces have been somewhat inadequate to heat the building, though this may be due in some measure, to the fact that some of the main steam pipes have lost considerable portions of their asbestos insulation. There is, as Mr Currie states, no hot water system in the building, which means considerable labour when bathing the pupils.

With regard to drinking water, I may say that on more than one occasion, I suggested to Mr Pitts, Mr Currie's predecessor, that he should send a sample of the water to the Manitoba Agricultural College.

Dear Sirs,-

On behalf of the Council Executive of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, I am writing you in regard to Birtle Indian Residential School.

I know that you have been informed both by Principal Currie and myself about the condition of that School, but my object in writing now is to ask if the Department will not take some action in regard to the building. We have all, as far as our Society is concerned, come to the conclusion that to spend any money either on the building or on furnishings and supplies, is putting good money into bad.

We are, as an Executive, desirous that any Institution under our management should be a credit to our Church. Of this Institution we are ashamed.

We appointed some new members of staff this fall, two have already sent in their resignations owing to conditions in the School, the other members are I know living under very poor conditions and to the detriment of their health.

This summer a convention of medical men was held in Brandon. Some Ontario doctors were present and were taken by one of the Brandon doctors out to see a case in Birtle School which had attracted some special attention. One of these doctors took the trouble on his return to come to the office and give us his opinion of the School. It was that it was a little better than a poor stable. Also that the children committed to our care were in poor health, and the sanitary conditions in the School were very bad.

The Department will know from your nurse in what a state she found the pupils.

We therefore would respectfully ask if you would include in your estimates a sum for building a new School at
Birtle, at as early a date as possible.

On behalf of our Society, we promise our fullest and heartiest co-operation.

On behalf of Council Executive,

Yours truly,

(Wm.) William W. Strachan

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith my report respecting Birtle Boarding School, for the month of September 1927, and as supplementing that report, I beg to state that the school was visited on the 20th instant by the Deputy Superintendent General, the Indian Commissioner, and Dr Corbett of Regina. These gentlemen made a thorough inspection of the school building, and were anything but favourably impressed. The Deputy Superintendent General advocated making several changes, namely closing up the part of the building that had been used as a boys' play room, using one of the rooms in the class room building for a dormitory, and making one of the dormitories into a play room; also getting the laundry department out of the basement into one of the small cottages to the east of the main building.

The Principal later thought out another scheme, which would do away with the necessity of using a class room for a dormitory, and that was to use the pupils' dining room for the girls' play room between meals, and close what had been the girls' play room in the basement, for the boys' play room. To do this, all that would be needed would be a partition with a door in it built across the hall to separate the girls' and boys' play rooms. This door would be kept locked, of course, except when it was necessary to admit the boys to the dining room for meals. The school work can then be carried on in the class rooms as usual. It is hoped that this change will have the approval of the Deputy Superintendent General.

With regard to the laundry, I beg to report that some delay has been experienced in getting one of the cottages fixed up for this purpose, owing to the school farming instructor being ill, necessitating the Principal attending to the farm work personally, and no carpenters being available. Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, relative to the fire equipment on hand at the Birtle Indian Residential School.

With reference to the providing of a suitable ladder from the junior girls' dormitory, I beg to say that if you consider this type of fire escape suitable you may arrange for the purchase and installation of a ladder of the required length. Would it not, however, be more suitable to install a sliding pole. This pole could be so arranged that the descent would be broken by a balcony. If you would prefer a sliding pole rather than a ladder, you should obtain prices for the supplying and installing of same, and submit the prices received for the consideration of the Department. I shall be pleased if you will give this matter your early consideration.

Relative to a refill for the 5 gallon pump tank Pyrene extinguisher, we are informed that water makes a satisfactory refill, provided it is not used in putting out fire occasioned by burning oil, gasoline or where electrical equipment is installed. If, however, you require a freeze-proof solution, you may place an order for a refill for this extinguisher with the Pyrene Manufacturing Co. of Canada Ltd., 1197 King St. W., Toronto, Ont., and forward their account, in duplicate, which you should certify and send to the Department for payment. Should you require refills for the 4 Guardene extinguishers, you may also place an order with the above firm. I am enclosing herewith for your information a pamphlet showing the different types of Pyrene extinguishers and giving full particulars regarding their use.

Should you obtain a ladder for use from the junior girls' dormitory instead of a sliding pole as suggested, you should obtain an account, in duplicate, which you should certify, and forward to the Department for payment.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No; 106-1-5 dated October 15th 1927 regarding the changes being made at the Birtle Residential School.

With regard to the laundry work of the school, as mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter, I beg to state that I immediately took the matter up with the school Principal. The Principal wrote to the Rumford Laundry at Brandon Man; asking what their rates would be for doing the school laundry work. A copy of their reply is attached hereto.

A sample bundle was sent to the Rumford Laundry, and has now been returned. The cost, at their list price was $54.07, less a discount of 40%, making the net cost for the work $32.45. The express charges one way amounted to $4.77, making the net cost $27.68;

The Principal had paid the express charges both ways, $4.57 to send the package to Brandon, and $4.77 for returning it; but as the Company agreed to pay charges one way, $4.77 should be deducted from the account which they rendered, of $32.45, which makes the account $27.68, net.

In their letter, enclosing the account, the Rumford Laundry L'td have agreed to do the laundry work for the school, for a flat rate of $30.00 per week, if shipped all in one consignment, all express charges to be paid by the school. A copy of this letter is also attached. At this flat rate of $30.00 per week, plus shipping charges, the school laundry work would cost practically $40.00 per week, which works out at about .45¢ per pupil per week.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that when at the Birtle Agency recently, I visited the residential school, as instructed, with a view to noting what had been done towards carrying out the suggested improvements in the building.

The playroom, formerly used by the girls, has been turned over to the boys. A partition has been put in the hall leading to the outside entrance of this building so that the boys have direct access to their playroom from the outside and cannot gain access to the rest of the building from this entry. The dining room is now being used as a playroom for the girls and the arrangement appears to be working very satisfactorily.

One of the old cottages is being fitted up as a laundry and a water conveyer pipe has been put in. The work in this building has not been completed and it is not expected that it will be fit for use during the severe weather. In the meantime the laundry work has been done by a woman in Birtle and when I was at the Agency the Principal received an offer from the Humford Laundry Co., in Brandon, who quoted a forty cent reduction from off their regular list prices and also agreed to pay the express charges one way. He has sent a trial shipment to them.

This building, as you know, owing to its narrow and intricate passages would be a death trap in case of fire. It would be impossible to make an escape, if a fire were in progress, through the passages and entrances. The present fire escape is at the back of the old building and consists of

FIRE PROTECTION (Cont'd.)

consists of an iron platform and an iron stair leading to the top of a lean-to from which there is a drop of over 6 ft. to the ground. The small boys can get on the fire escape direct from their dormitory; the big boys have to pass through the hall to the small boys' dormitory. The girls have to pass through the matron's room in order to gain access to the fire escape. The latter arrangement is not satisfactory.

With reference to fire fighting equipment, they have a 40 barrel tank in the attic with a stand pipe and new linen hose on each floor. In addition to this, they have four 2½ gal. fire extinguishers, four of the small Johns Manville extinguishers, and one 5 gal. pump tank. The Principal informs me that he is having weekly fire drill but does not turn the water into the hose as the linen hose, for the first few minutes, leaks a certain amount and makes a mess in the building. There is no fire escape from the dormitory in the north wing. This is a comparatively new addition to the school. In taking the matter up with the Principal, he informed me that he had authority to put in an escape and will do so at once. I gave him the necessary information as to where he could secure a pole fire escape, which was thought to be satisfactory.

CONDITION OF BUILDING.

The building, as you know, is a very old one and should be replaced. This applies to the barns and out-buildings which are old and in poor repair. The only decent building in connection with this school is the classroom which is quite new and a good building.

While I found the interior of the building clean and well kept, there was a very noticeable smell of sewer gas and in some of the rooms it was very objectionable.

This gas
CONDITION OF BUILDING (Cont'd.)

This gas is backing up from the septic tank, which is evidently not working satisfactorily or else the traps may be defective.

The building is heated with two steam furnaces. These furnaces are very old and leaking. I noted that the furnaces are not provided with steam gauges and I could not find any information as to when they were last inspected or whether they had ever been inspected. The Principal, who has a certificate as an engineer, appears to be afraid of these furnaces. There is no doubt that they are very old and should be inspected. Their safety at the present time is in that they have several leaks which may prevent the pressure from getting too high.

FARM.

A farm, consisting of 160 acres 2½ miles distant from the school, is operated. They had 90 acres in oats which was reported as being a poor crop; I did not see it. Their garden, however, produced 3,000 bus. of potatoes, as well as roots and other vegetables.

Their stock consists of 16 cows, 5 calves, 26 hogs, 6 work horses and 2 drivers. They are milking 8 cows at present and will have other cows freshening during the winter which will keep up their supply of milk. Their stock I found in splendid condition.

PUPILAGE

There are 91 pupils enrolled; of these 5 were absent on account of sickness. The children have been very healthy and they have had none in the hospital for six months. I was present when the children were having their evening meal and noted that their food was ample and wholesome. The meals consist of the following:

Breakfast

Breakfast
Porridge with milk and brown sugar,
Bread & butter with fruit or Peanut Butter.

Dinner
Meat and vegetables with raisin biscuite and apples.

Supper
Meat or soup with fruit and bread and butter.

Milk and tea are provided for drink at each meal.

The Principal of the school, Mr. Currie, and his wife, who acts as matron, impress me as being very practical and capable people for this position. I believe they have the interests of their pupils and of their work very much at heart. Considering the condition of the building, it is kept in remarkably good shape. This is a difficult building to keep clean and tidy.

I may say that when visiting the Waywayssecoppo Reserve the Indians there informed me that they had held a meeting amongst themselves and had passed a resolution agreeing to set aside a half section of land in the north east corner of the reserve in close proximity to Bird Tail Siding, and they are very anxious to have the school located closer to their reserve than the present location.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to forward herewith a report on the Birtle Indian Residential School, which was inspected by Mr. Murison during the month of November.

As you had a report on this school by Mr. Hamilton in June, and visited it yourself personally in September you will have a pretty good idea of the conditions existing there. It seems to me that nothing can be done to improve matters, and that the only solution is a new school. I intend going to Winnipeg shortly and will ascertain from the Provincial Government if they are prepared to dispose of their Experimental Farm at Birtle. You will remember we learned while at Birtle that this might possibly be procured. I have been going to do this but time has not permitted of my getting to Winnipeg.

To put in new boilers and spend thousands of dollars on this school seems to me to be impracticable. It is not so bad in the summer but it is very unsatisfactory and dangerous during the winter.

Yours very truly,

Dear Dr. Scott,

As the Federal Budget has now been before the House for some time, you will soon know if the appropriation for our new school will be available for the present year's building. I wish to know this just as soon as the information is available as it will materially affect my plans for the coming year along several lines.

In view of my experience during the past few months, I feel like asking you to press the matter of securing us a new school during the present year.

The changes we have made, in new playroom for the boys—change of Laundry to Cottage—and an adequate milk supply—have materially benefited the health of the pupils. We have had a few colds and coughing at the present time, but the health of the pupils has been good. You will be pleased to learn we have had no serious...
Birtle, Man.

Illness since last July - The cows you gave us the money to buy are proving real producers. Recently two of them have freshened and are giving over 35 and 40 lbs each per day. We now have over a pint of milk per day for each pupil, and members of staff - all milk is used whole. Butter so far is purchased. The two new power washers you secured for us work satisfactorily - and handle the heavy end of the laundry work.

The heating plant is the one thing that I cannot help worrying about. I have been able to keep the residence fairly comfortable - but at an excessive cost; I do not get results from the fuel consumed. I am on my sixth car load of coal now, and will require one more car yet to put us through. That is we have used 197 tons, but we through, that is we have used 197 tons, when the present supply is used up and another car that will be required, will be about 33 tons more or a total of 230 tons. Most of these has cost me $10 a ton, so the season's fuel is over $2000.00 for Coal - we use considerable wood also - at least 50 cords. This makes a decided tax on our finances. One car of Coal I have not yet paid for - would it be possible for you to arrange for payment of same? I will enclose the account.
To keep the building comfortable, the furnace requires constant attention. I have never gone to bed before twelve or one o'clock all winter. During severe spells I stay up till after four and sometimes until my farmer comes on duty at six. The furnaces are not safe, and I cannot forget that over ninety are asleep, under my care. I am a licensed Steam Heating Engineer and while others that might know less about conditions, might take chances, I cannot do it. And for the safety of my pupils during the winter 1928-1929 I would urge that no effort be left unused to secure our new School for Birtle in 1927.

I know you will do all you can for us, and I felt it might strengthen your position to have the result of my observation and experience during the present firing season.

Yours faithfully,

H.B. Currie.
March 23, 1928.

Dear Mr. Currie:

I have your letter of the 11th instant and am very pleased to learn that the recent changes and improvements at the Birtle Indian Residential School have materially benefitted the health of the pupils. I am convinced you are doing your best in a difficult situation, and the fact that an experienced principal is in charge at present is a matter of much satisfaction to the Department and to me, personally.

The chief needs in connection with Presbyterian Church Indian educational work are new buildings at the Cecilia Jeffrey and Birtle Schools. Cecilia Jeffrey has always had precedence and I am happy to inform you that funds will shortly be available for the initial capital expenditure there. There must inevitably be a delay before a new building can be provided for the Birtle Indian Residential School. This means carrying on for the time being or the alternative, which would be to close the school. After all, the first considerations are the pupils' health and safety, which are at present in jeopardy.

The first question to be answered is: can the activity be continued in the present building if special assistance is given by the Department? I could arrange to appoint a competent night watchman for the winter months and could favourably consider meeting special expenditure, made necessary by unsanitary or other unsatisfactory conditions. If you feel that the school should not be kept open, even with special assistance, I believe you should lay the facts before the church authorities.

I am returning the account for a carload of coal. Expenses for fuel are purely current in character and, as such, will have to be met by the per capita grant or other earnings. Rest assured, however, that I am prepared to help in other ways.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Mr. Orr,

I am returning one set of the plans you sent of the proposed Indian School, Birtle.

I wish to offer the following suggestions based on my experience in the Church School at Alberni, burned in 1917, the new Government School completed at Alberni in 1920, and the present Indian School at Birtle. My first suggestion, and this would necessitate a change of the whole proposed plan, would be a detached Class Rooms or Class Rooms in a wing by themselves. This suggestion I made to Dr. Scott when he was here in 1927. And my experience in the three above schools convinces me that for in the main building and to have the Class Rooms in the Recreation Room under the Class Rooms, that there is so much noise in the Recreation Room that it disturbs the pupils in the Class Room. The Recreation Room is about 30 feet wide, necessitating a row of strong pillars down the centre often used by pupils at play and perhaps sometimes on purpose. We found it allow the pupils to use the Recreation Room during school hours that Class Room work was so disturbed that almost daily the Class Room teacher had to send the Class Room to speak to boys that started to play all right but gradually in excitement got boisterous again about once a week the dormitories above the Class Room.

were scrubbed and the moving of the beds across the floor caused too much noise in the Class Room. Again Class Room Pupils coming out and going into Class Room at 9 am. Recess in morning - noon out and in; recess at 2.30 p.m. and at 4 p.m. Made a lot of noise in the residence especially noticeable when sick pupils were in the School. The detailed Class Room or in an adjoining wing for School only would largely overcome this.

On the Basement Plan where the heating plant is about on the same level, the steam radiators have to be hung on the ceiling to get proper drainage for condensation water. Special extra radiator surface should be provided. The Basement was always very degrees colder than the rest of the house and to make the Basement comfortable the rest of the house was to heat. This applies particularly to the Bath Rooms off the Boys and Girls Recreation Rooms. These Baths appear to be the principal baths for the pupils - and they were so cold it was almost impossible to use them, also they were not conveniently located for these reasons. No Clothing Store Room is near for the clean clothes and it is far from the laundry for the dirty clothes. But these matters were less important, but being too cold was a chief objection. But as a preference I would suggest the main Bath Rooms be near Dormitories. The general arrangement of your Basement floor is good. One door from the kitchen, on the left hand side, out into the Boys yard should be added so that boys would not have to carry kitchen refuse out through the girls yard - as would now have to done unless it were taken away out through the boiler Room or through dining Room.
There is no provision in the basement for dairy room or cold storage. Of course you may have in mind other provision for these—some place in building—not on ground floor—a disinfecting room should be provided. This is quite important, to disinfect bedding after illness, also we receive considerable supplies from women's church societies that provide us with boxes of clothing. All such second-hand supplies should pass through the disinfecting room before being put into use, as one never knows what disease germs they may contain.

As far as possible, for Manitoba, keep all water pipes away from outside walls.

Ground Floor

Swing doors should be put on one end of the main hall on ground and first floor, to avoid drafts.

If present plan with class rooms in main building is used, the ground floor is about all one could wish.

First Floor

I see no provision for fire escape from the boys' and girls' dormitories, on each end of building.

One suggestion re this floor is that the bed-room between girls' infirmary and girls' dormitory bath-room be discarded and about five feet more added to the pupils' bath-rooms on this floor. This would mean shifting infirmary quarters about six feet to the right hand.

So far as I can gather there are no outside sleeping balconies—might such be provided.

The dormitories are quite large about 52 x 28 feet.
I am inclined to favor small dormitories, you can make better division of your pupils, especially for your Jr. pupils—and your very little ones. Here there is a small dormitory for 8 Jr. girls, and I like it well. The small dormitory requires more supervision, but is better for the pupils.

Second Floor:
This floor is all right but for toilet provision. This would have to be installed, and I think it would be easy to put in as the plan shows. Bath rooms on the first floor. A bath tub here might be unnecessary—but the toilet and bowl & slop sinks are necessary.

Perhaps no one item, in a Manitoba School, is as important as an efficient, economical heating system.

I have read considerable on construction, It is a line I am interested in and had some practical experience, and am anxious that the new Birtle School will be such that it will serve as model for your future buildings—serve as model for your future buildings—serve as model for your future buildings—serve as model for your future buildings—

Is this suggestion any good Mr. Orr, discard the second floor, only have basement, ground & first floors, use Class Rooms I have marked.
One and three, in lieu of the dormitories on the Second Floor, Extend Class Room No. 1 to dotted line, to increase size of dormitory. Add toilet in No. 1 Class Room to connect to waste from Bath Room on First floor. Class Room No. 2 to be used as Clothing Store Room, and disinfecting Room. Entering Store Room from dormitory and disinfecting Room from Store Room. The toilet in No. 3 Class Room to connect with Waste pipe from Bath on First Floor.

This uses the Class Rooms, takes children from Second Floor, making it safer in case of fire — easier to cope with fire in case of accident, the high building requiring greater pressure to reach with water, and necessitates providing other Class Rooms in lieu of the present top or Second Floor.

I trust the Estimate for our School meets with no opposition, in Parliament, that the site may be procured at once and the tenders called for the building just as soon as the money is assured — so that an early spring start may be made yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

We have been advised that you are contemplating the erection of a $250,000 Indian School at Birtle, Manitoba.

Concerned as you are with construction, undoubtedly you are familiar with the uses of Copper, Brass and Bronze products and with their merits as building materials. We would appreciate your consideration of these metals for the projects in which you are interested.

Copper, Brass and Bronze are well suited for those parts of buildings where deterioration first shows itself, namely roofing, sheet metal work, plumbing, hardware, lighting fixtures, and screens. Short-lived materials cause much damage by failure. Repairs and replacements necessarily follow. Yet many persons still believe it is economical to save the small difference in price between corroding materials and Copper, Brass and Bronze for these purposes. At the same time they demand the best in lumber or brick.

We are enclosing a partial list of our publications. You will see they include both technical and non-technical books. Copies of any or all are available to you at any time. May we send them?

The services of our Research Department and our Building Service Department are also at your disposal without cost or obligation in the solution of any problem which may arise in connection with the use of metals in building construction.

Yours very truly,

Copper & Brass Research Association,

Dear Mr. Currie:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the building programme for the Birtle Indian Residential School.

A few days ago, Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham's recommendation, that a site be selected on the Waywayseecappo Reserve, was approved and Mr. Graham was requested to have you accompany whatever officer made the selection of the farm and building site. I believe the opposition you anticipate from the other Indian reserves would be but temporary, and, if necessary, the Department would enforce the compulsory clauses of the Indian Act. The Waywayseecappo Reserve, from the Department's standpoint, has many advantages. There would be practically no expenditure for the site and farm. It would be on the line of railway which has direct railway connection with the Keeseekoosein and Rolling River Reserves. Further, excellent agricultural land can be secured. Sir,

I beg to forward herewith my Report respecting the Birtle Indian Residential School, for the month of September. I did not make a report for the month of August, as the pupils and staff were just getting settled into routine work after the close of vacation, and the returning of the pupils.

The pupils returned to school after vacation this year, much more promptly than in any previous year in my experience, and without any having to be brought back.

I was in the class rooms at 4 p.m. when the school was dismissed, and two boys commenced to sweep the rooms without the use of anything on the floor to keep down the dust. I recommended to the Principal in the evening, on my second visit to the school, that Dustbane, or some such preparation should be used, for the sake of the health of the children, and he said that he would see that this was done.

The heating system in the main building is in very bad shape; in fact, in my opinion it is a danger, and someone will need to be on duty 24 hours of the day looking after it this winter. This, I understand, will be the case. I impressed upon the Principal, the importance of fire drill, especially at this time of the year, and the heating system being in its present poor condition.

Your obedient Servant

The Ass't Deputy and Secretary

I beg to advise you that Mr H.B.Currie, Principal of the Birtle Indian Residential School, has been speaking to me regarding the housing of the school cattle during the coming winter.

Sir,

I beg to advise that when I was at the Birtle Indian Residential School a few days ago, Mr Currie, the Principal, discussed with me the outbuildings that would be required in connection with the proposed new school, and requested me to forward the enclosed sketches he has made, of what are his ideas for a Cattle barn, and a Horse barn. In addition, there will be required, a Pig pen, to accommodate 50 pigs, and a Poultry house for from 200 to 300 hens. Mr Currie states that he would like to have these buildings started as soon as possible, in order that they may be ready for the school stock before fall.

It is also necessary that the pasture that has been purchased from the Town of Birtle, be fenced as soon as possible, as at present, outside cattle have access to this pasture. This would require about 450 Split Cedar fence posts, 6 - 6" X 8' round cedar posts for corners, about 12 Pcs 4X4-16' for braces; 1½ miles of Woven Wire fencing, 50" high, and 16 Rolls (40 Rods each), of Barbed Wire. All the fencing material required can be purchased locally.

Will you kindly advise me if the fencing may be proceeded with immediately? Competitive prices would of course be obtained for the materials.

Your obedient Servant,

Dear Sir;

Re: Birtle Indian Residential School.

I made another visit of inspection to Birtle on July 30th, and while there telegraphed you that I advised an increase of the footings from 26" to 32", and I am in receipt of your reply saying that you approve of this.

When the excavation was started the foreman found that he could not get a plow into the ground in order to use fresh air to take out the earth; there was a solid rock and boulder formation to a depth of about five feet or somewhat less. The only way to successfully overcome this was to put a large steam shovel to work, and the shipping of this from Winnipeg took about a week. When I arrived last Wednesday they had the main excavation out and expected to finish with the shovel on Saturday. Below this hard formation we ran into light clay which I thought would be better with a slightly wider spread of footing. I enclose one or two photographs to show the material excavated and the shovel at work, also a view of the property with the site indicated.

Claydon Ltd., have ample equipment on the ground to put the job through quickly; the bunk houses and cook houses are up and things are moving along in a business like way.

I drove out to the sand pits with the foreman and examined the sand they intend to use. This is quite good.

I enclose herewith my account to the end of July on this job. You will note that I have to leave Punnichy at 3.50 a.m. and return the next morning at 3.30 a.m., making a full twenty-four hour trip.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir;

Since my report of Aug. 2nd., I have made two trips to Birtle the last of which was yesterday.
I find that the work is going along very well, and that materials are being delivered as required.
The foundations are all in and most of the basement walls.
The contractors have a rock crusher on the job and are crushing up the boulders for the crushed stone.
The brick and tile are being delivered in large quantities, and yesterday I had a corner set up so that we could arrange for the best joint with the "Rug-Tex" National Clay Products brick which I understand you approved for the face.
The steel is on the job, and is being supplied by the Dominion Bridge Co. of Winnipeg. In this connection, and appos of our little trouble with the Winnipeg Bridge Co. on the Muscowequan school, I might mention that I noticed some of the small angle irons for the window openings were stamped Illinois which certainly does not look like Canadian material.
The Dominion Bridge claim that all steel sections up to 10" I beams are rolled in Canada, but they have 8" I beams on this job that are marked Illinois.
Will you please let me know by return what floors you want in the principal's residence? I told the foreman that I considered that some of them would be wooden floors.

I am of the opinion that more blackboard space should be provided in the class rooms.

It is proposed to construct a septic tank identical in size and construction with that constructed at the new Brandon School last fall, and making no provision for disposal bed.
