Dear Sir;

Re: Birtle Indian School.

I have this morning returned from Birtle where I have investigated the complaint about the concrete. I find that the concrete basement walls are now finished, and that they are a good average job of concrete, and above the average for foundation walls. In stripping there were several places where the corners of piers had been knocked off, but not enough to make any structural difference. I chopped into the wall in several places, and also tried to drive 2½" nails in. In no case could I get a nail in half way before it would bend over. Under separate cover I am sending you a piece of the concrete which I chopped from the wall. I am sending this because of all places tested this appears to show the least amount of crushed rock, being a piece where some of the smaller stone had accumulated. It might be interesting to have this tested for compression. As mentioned in previous reports the contractors are crushing the stone on the job, using the field stone taken from the excavation. I have sent a sample of this, taken from the crusher, with the concrete, and I have also enclosed a sample of the coarse sand which I had them mix with this.

I am interested to learn from whom the complaint about this work came, and to know if they have any real knowledge of building construction or not. It is very easy for a person to state that a piece of work is bad, but quite another matter to say why and to show how it should have been done. Of course I have only been on this job about once a week, but I believe from my own observations that the Department are getting a very reasonable grade of work.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Re: Birtle School.

While at Birtle yesterday one or two points came up that had been discussed by the Principal's wife and the Indian Agent.

First they wanted the domestic coal room on the Kitchen wall with a door to kitchen. I sanctioned the change to that side of the store room but with the door still in the store room on account of coal dust. I also thought that a door into store Rm. at foot of the side entrance steps would be allowed.

They very much want to have eight of the wash basins taken from the basement and placed in the present clothing stores on dormitory floor, to save the children making a trip down to the basement to wash and then back up again to complete dressing. This awaits your approval. I think it would be a good idea to do this and to carry the partitions over enough so that the fire escapes open into these wash-rooms. There will be no change much on the plumbing as the stack up to the top lavatory in dormitories will take care of these basins.

I have not yet heard what floors are wanted in the principal's residence, but would suggest birch for living rooms and edge grain fir for bedrooms. Kitchen could be linoleum.

Dear Sir;

Re. Birtle Indian School.

On my arrival at Birtle yesterday I found Mr. Henderson just starting his duties as superintendent of construction. We went over the job together and discussed the various points that had come up since the work was started. Mr. Henderson had received no instructions except the telegram from your office, but we assumed that he would be taking charge, and that it would not be necessary for me to make any further trips.

I am enclosing progress photos showing the work a week ago, but since then the concrete slab has been run on the main building at ground floor level, and the rear wing built up and steel joints on ready for concrete. The heating boilers are on the job, and the plumbers have most of the underground pipes in.

It is now becoming very imperative that the contractor should know where the water supply is coming into the building, where the electric power supply is coming in, and if a meter room or switch board is to be provided for, if the washrooms on dormitory floor are to be provided, and if laundry machinery is to be electrically driven or an engine provided.

The contractor is going ahead and only providing for linoleum on the corridors.

In taking up the matter of the steel angle irons with the Dominion Bridge Co., they inform me that they shipped from their Winnipeg stock in an effort to rush the order, and some of the angles were rolled in the U.S.A. As we have had to use some of these to proceed with the work I have dropped the matter.

From now on I am assuming that all correspondence in regard to this job will go direct to Mr. Henderson at Birtle.

MEMORANDUM:

Hon. Thomas G. Murphy,

With reference to the concrete work in the new Birtle School on receipt of your telegram I instructed Mr. Swan, the Acting Inspector of Construction, to proceed at once to Birtle and submit a report on the concrete work for this building.

The following is the report received from Mr. Swan dated August 28th:-

"I have this morning returned from Birtle where I have investigated the complaint about the concrete. I find that the concrete basement walls are now finished, and that they are a good average job of concrete, and above the average for foundation walls. In stripping there were several places where the corners of piers had been knocked off, but not enough to make any structural difference. I chopped into the wall in several places and also tried to drive 2½" nails in. In no case could I get a nail in half way before it would bend over. Under separate cover I am sending you a piece of the concrete which I chopped from the wall. I am sending this because of all places tested this appears to show the least amount of crushed rock, being a piece where some of the smaller stone had accumulated. It might be interesting to have this tested for compression. As mentioned in previous reports the contractors are crushing the stone on the job, using the field stone taken from the excavation. I have sent a sample of this, taken from the crusher, with the concrete, and I have also enclosed a sample of the coarse sand which I had them mix with this.

I am interested to learn from whom the complaint about this work came, and to know if they have any real knowledge of building construction or not. It is very easy for a person to state that a piece of work is bad, but quite another matter to say why and to show how it should have been done. Of course I have only been on this job about once a week, but I believe from my observations that the Department are getting a reasonable grade of work."

Dear Sir:

We have had the privilege of submitting a quotation to a contracting firm in Winnipeg on the equipment you propose installing in the Indian School barn at Birtle, Manitoba. In taking off this specification we had an opportunity of examining the plan and we would respectfully submit the following suggestions as an improvement in regard to the layout of the four pens at the end of the building. According to the plan as it now stands the gate is placed in the centre of the front opening out on to the alley way, providing for a manger on one side, 4' in length and provision at the other side of the gate being made for a Water Bowl only.

We are of the opinion that the proper place for these Water Bowls would be in the cross partition and the attached pencil sketch will help to illustrate what we mean. The Water Bowl for one pen is set in the opposite pan and a large opening provided to allow the animal to drink through. We can supply Water Bowl Shields to protect the Water Bowls and keep rubbish and other matter from getting into the Bowl from the pen in which it is situated. We have found from experience that this is the most satisfactory method of placing Water Bowls in pens.

Then by hanging both pen gates on the post at the centre of the pen front, this will permit of you using an 8' manger instead of 4' as on the present plan. This type of installation is if anything more rigid, owing to this corner post going further into the concrete and the lower bars of the gate frame, as illustrated in our barn book on page 162, will extend across both the gate openings and being embedded in the cement will still further strengthen these two gates.

We might add that the changes suggested will in no way add to the cost of these pens but will on the other hand mean added convenience on account of the gates swinging to the centre points in both cases and prevent to a large extent any chances of the animals crowding over.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,

Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I have had a second visit from Rev. D. J. Graham, Deputy Principal, at Birtle. He is well pleased with progress being made.

(1) Re Laundry Walls.

Rev. D. J. Graham asked if walls will be plastered and suggests that the walls should be done with cement. He also thinks that boy's and girl's recreation rooms should be similarly done in cement. As this will cost no more I await your approval of same.

(2) Re Plan of Dairy.

Rev. D. J. Graham noticed that workmen have to pass through dairy to get to pump room and asked what could be done to overcome this. I showed him that stair down to boiler room could be moved forward four or five feet; landing extended; door cut through wall into pump room; door between dairy and pump room closed up; same door being used. I found that the form work for stair is constructed and have stopped concrete pouring until you consider these suggestions.
(3) Re Rear Entrance to Boiler Room.

Electric light is shown in vestibule. I suggest that it would be more serviceable to have another fixture outside above door for the convenience of the fireman at night.

(4) Re Veranda Roof of Balcony to Boy's Class Room.

No rain water down pipe is shown on plan to take charge of rain water on this veranda roof. As this is a small balcony I suggest that a two inch galvanized down pipe on roof down corner and discharging into Weeping Tavern could be used.

These suggestions I mention for your consideration and approval.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.

R. Guerney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian School
Birtle, Manitoba

Replying to your letter of September 17th we enclose herewith our Trade Summary showing how our contract is made up.

We are rather short handed in the office for a few days, and the writer also expects to be away from the city returning possibly the end of next week. The detailed estimate, as requested, will be attended to as soon as possible after that time. We trust, however, the Trade Summary enclosed will be of some service to you in the meantime.

Sometime ago we wired the Department about getting in sewer and water service. To date we have not heard anything about it. The water supply will be difficult to obtain as soon as the frosty nights set in. In the meantime we have a thousand feet of pipe line from the railway water tank, but as soon as the nights are frosty, and this may occur any time, we shall probably be in trouble with it. Is it possible for a permanent water supply to be attended to without further delay?

The plumbing and heating contractor has taken some plant on the job which need electric current. We shall also need temporary lights. We have been trying to get some local information as to the running of a supply line, but were not successful in getting anything done. May we ask if this can be attended to at an early date, as it will be impossible to open School without it, and we would certainly appreciate the use of both water and light as early as possible.

Yours truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED

Dear Mr. Orr;

Re: Birtle Indian School.

On Tuesday the 16th I received a telegram from Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau, asking that I meet him in Birtle to discuss the water supply for the School. On Friday we met there and went over the matter at some length. The actual scheme for the water supply I need not go into here as Mr. Gow will undoubtedly have sent the Department a full report. What I do want your approval of is the using of certain rooms and the consequent changes in part of basement layout. To show this more clearly I have outlined the basement plan and indicated in red the portions that will be effected.

With the proposed scheme it will be necessary to house a pressure tank, a chlorinator, a filter (similar to Gordons) and pump. These can well go into the rooms marked as Dairy and Pump Rm., and we could place the Dairy in some other place; maybe in one of the two suggested places indicated on my sketch. May I mention in this regard that for the way in which they use this room it would be more convenient next to the Kitchen or Dining Rm.

If you adopted suggestion No. 2 on the plan it might be as well to eliminate the corridor into the Dining Rm.

I see no real hardship in having to take the domestic coal down the rear entrance and into room indicated in suggestion No. 1. This will be carried into the kitchen in scuttles.

I am sending a copy of the enclosed sketch to Mr. Gow and also to Mr. Henderson on the job. Will you wire both of them your decision in the matter of changes so that the least amount of delay may occur?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Orr:

Re. Birtle Indian School

On Tuesday the 16th I received a telegram from Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, asking that I meet him at Birtle to discuss the water supply for the School. On Friday we met there and went over the matter at some length. The actual scheme for the water supply I need not go into here as Mr. Gow will undoubtedly have sent the Department a full report. What I do want your approval of is the using of certain rooms and the consequent changes in part of the basement layout. To show this more clearly I have outlined the basement plan and indicated in red the portions that will be affected.

With the proposed scheme it will be necessary to house a pressure tank, a chlorinator, a filter (similar to Gordons) and pump. These can well go into the rooms marked as Dairy and Pump Room, and we could place the Dairy in some other place; maybe in one of the two suggested places indicated on my sketch. May I mention in this regard that for the present way in which they use this room it would be more convenient next to the Kitchen or Dining Room. If you adopted suggestion No. 2 on the plan it might be as well to eliminate the corridor into the Dining Room.

I see no real hardship in having to take the Domestic Coal down the rear entrance and into rooms indicated in suggestion No. 1. This will be carried into the Kitchen in scuttles.

I am sending a copy of the enclosed sketch to Mr. Gow and also to Mr. Henderson on the job. Will you wire both of them your decision in the matter of changes so that the least amount of delay may occur?

Yours Sincerely,

(W. Swan)

Winnipeg, Sept. 25, 1930.
PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY
FOR
BIRTLE INDIAN SCHOOL.

Source of Supply.

The primary source of water supply for the new Indian School at Birtle is Birdtail Creek. The Canadian Pacific Railway Company maintains a pumping plant on the creek bank and pumps water to their water tank adjoining the railway nearly one mile distant. The pumping plant is modern, efficient and when traffic is heavy about 80,000 to 100,000 gallons of water are pumped daily, the tank being filled at least twice daily. The new school is located approximately 1,600 feet from the railway water tank. The Canadian Pacific Railway Company has agreed to supply water for the new school upon the following general terms:

(1) The water supply to be drawn from their water tank and not from their pipe line.

(2) The water supply pipe connection to the pipe line to the school to extend at least 7'-0" above the bottom of their water tank so that at no time can the school drain the railway tank.

(3) The water supply to the school to be metered and water used to be paid for at the rate of 25 cents per 1,000 gallons.

(4) The meter to be supplied by and installed at the expense of the school and all pipe connections to the water tank are to be made at no expense to the Railway Company.

(5) The Railway Company does not accept responsibility for any deficiency in the water supply.

Purity of Supply.

The water will require to be filtered and chlorinated for domestic use.
PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM

General.

The following elevations are to be noted,

Elevations being to sea level datum:

Concrete base of C.P.R. water tank ........ 1707.25
Bottom of water tank ....................... 1725.25
Maximum water level in tank (full) ....... 1740.25
Outlet to school pipe line ................. 1732.25
Basement floor of new school .............. 1694.00
Water services in basement of school ...... 1697.00

With the water level in the water tank standing at elevation 1732.25 there would be a 35.25 foot head, less loss of head due to friction in the pipe line, on the water services in the basement of the school, so that if other conditions permitted a gravity water supply would be possible to the water services in the basement of the school where it is estimated 75 percent of the water supply will be used. Unfortunately there are other conditions that do not permit of a dependable water supply in the basement under the gravity system. When the water level in the railway tank drops below elevation 1732.25, as it will probably frequently do, no water is available for the school pipe line and as a short time would suffice to drain the water in the pipe line the school would be without water until such time as the Railway Company again filled their water tank. The domestic water supply must be chlorinated and to operate efficiently there must be a water pressure of at least 20 pounds per square inch on the feed pipe to the chlorinator and this pressure is not obtainable with a gravity system. There is apparently no necessity for chlorinating the water supply for the laundry or toilets and it is possible to
supply these services in the basement by gravity, except during those intervals when the water supply in the railway tank drops below 1732.25. I would, however, point out that the only advantage of a partial gravity system would be the considerable saving in pumping costs, but that this saving would not compensate for the inconvenience caused by lack of water supply for a few hours every now and then. Accordingly, I would recommend that the whole water supply for the school building be supplied through a pressure tank system. To ensure that the school would always have a day's water supply available it will be necessary to install a 5,000 gallon tank in the immediate vicinity of the school and preferably underground.

Proposed Installation.

The proposed installation for the water supply to the new school is as follows:

(1) A 3" meter to be installed in the enclosure under the Canadian Pacific Railway water tank.

(2) 1,650 feet of 2½" wrought iron pipe line running from the water tank through the meter to a 5,000 gallon storage tank.

(3) A cylindrical storage tank 6' 6" diameter and 25' 0" long, capacity 5,000 gallons and designed for a working pressure of 20# per square inch, heads to be 5/16" plate, flanged and dished, shell 1/4". The tank will be equipped with 11" x 15" manhole and all seams stitch rivetted and electrically welded. This tank will be placed 5' 0" underground and immediately adjacent to the rear of the pump and boiler rooms.
(4) One 1,500 gallon per hour self-oiling Typhoon pump, motor driven and mounted upon the same base as the 3 H.P. motor. The intake will be directly from the 5,000 gallon storage reservoir.

(5) The discharge from the pump will be through a short length of piping to the water filter, (similar in design and capacity to the filter in the Gordon School, Saskatchewan.

(6) From the filter the discharge will be directly into a 1,200 gallon pressure tank. This tank will be 4' 0" diameter and 16' 0" long and similar to the tank installed in the Brandon School. The pressure range in this tank will be between 50 and 100 pounds, which range is sufficient to meet all requirements.

(7) A small motor driven air compressor will be installed to maintain an adequate air pressure within the pressure tank.

(8) The discharge from the pressure tank will lead through the chlorinator. This chlorinator will probably be similar to the one in operation at the Cecilia Jeffrey School at Kenora. If it is so desired the water supply for the toilets and laundry room need not pass through the chlorinator but might be taken directly from a second outlet connection from the pressure tank.

Water Supply for Farm Buildings

The farm buildings will probably be located about 500 to 600 feet from the school and on slightly higher ground. It is proposed to lay a 1½" pipe line from the 5,000 gallon storage tank to the cattle barn with 1" piping from this line to other buildings. There will be
sufficient pressure to ensure a gravity system to these buildings during the greater portion of the time.

**Fire Protection**

The stand-pipes in the school will connect with the pressure tank system, giving a very limited amount of fire protection.

Sir:-

Swan, of Punnichy, Saskatchewan, at Birtle, this meeting being arranged at my request in order that I could discuss with him the most suitable water supply system for the school. This report being forwarded conforms very closely to the scheme discussed and decided upon at the meeting between Mr. Swan and myself. Sir,-

I note on looking through the correspondence relating to the Birtle School that there are a few letters in which questions have been asked that have not been answered, and I now wish to give you the particulars required.

It is not the intention to install eight of the wash basins from the basement in the present clothing room on the dormitory floor, the plumbing is to be installed as shown on the plans.

With reference to your letter of the 17th ultimo it will be satisfactory to have the walls in the laundry plastered with cement also the boys' and girls' recreation rooms.

With regard to item 2 in your letter I do not consider it necessary to make the changes asked for by the Rev. Mr. Graham. With reference to item 5 you may arrange to have the additional electric outlets provided as suggested.

Your suggestions for the drainage of the verandah roof is approved. I also approve of your suggestions re the changes in the high pressure boiler.

You may arrange for the connecting up of power to the building with the Hydro system.

With reference to the Rev. Mr. Graham's suggestion for a partition hall dividing the dormitories it is not considered that this change is necessary and the dormitories should therefore be provided as shown on the plans.

With regard to the fireplace in the Principal's residence it will be satisfactory to have this fireplace faced with pressed brick as suggested by Mr. Swan and 4 x 4 quarry tile used for the hearth. It is not considered that a detail is necessary as the fireplace is to be perfectly plain design with wood shelf on top. The fireplace is to be equipped with regular damper.

With reference to the radiation in the front vestibule it will be satisfactory to carry out Mr. Swan's suggestion or if arrangements can be made to install wall radiator same will be approved.
The cork insulation in the cold storage should be installed as provided in the specifications and I approve of your arrangement with regard to the doors.

Regarding the cupboards, lockers, tables, etc. required for this building I would ask you to kindly consult with the Reverend Principal and forward to the Department rough sketches showing all equipment that it is suggested being built into the building. When this information is received you will be further instructed.

With reference to your letter of the 6th you may arrange to have the doors provided from the vestries to the platform. You may also arrange to have a door provided between the kitchen and dining room in the Principal's residence. It is noted in paragraph 3 of your letter that one door can be dispensed with in the stores in the basement.

If the construction work is not too far advanced you may arrange to have a service opening provided between the servery and the dining room.

Will you please instruct the contractor to provide metal corner beads where required in the plastering.

Your suggestion regarding the trench for steam mains in the basement corridors is approved.

The Department accepts the price quoted by the contractors for the changes in the dairy as submitted in your letter of the 9th.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
SECRETARY.

Inspector of Construction,
Indian Residential School,
BIRTLIE, Man.

Agreement made in duplicate the Eighteenth day of August, 1930.

A. D.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

AND

Clayden Company Limited,

of Winnipeg, Man., (hereinafter called the Contractors).

The Contractors for themselves, their heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agree to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractors and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose the erection and completion of Birtle Indian Residential School, near Birtle, Man., according to specification No. 616, containing sheets 1 - 88 inclusive, and plan No. 616, containing sheets No. 1 - 12 inclusive, as recorded in the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the 20th day of February, 1931.

A. D.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractors the Superintendent General hereby agree to pay the said Contractors the sum of One hundred and thirty-thousand dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any, due to the Contractors after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractors under this contract.

AND the Contractors for themselves their executors, administrators and assigns, further covenant and agree:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractors fail at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractors for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such account and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractors, and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractors fail at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by them upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractors and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractors shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whosoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

Dear Sir:

Re Horse Barn.

No water trough is called for. We have decided to place water trough on East end of cow and horse barn, outside for horses to drink, about nine feet long with water supply pipe passing through gable into trough with shut off valve inside to stop from freezing. This should be a metal trough. Contractor Doig has submitted an estimate of $30.00 for a trough nine feet long. I will be pleased to have your approval of same.

Re Box Stalls in Cow Manger shown in these box stalls. They are not adapted for calves. These mangers call for Concrete mangers, low down. Mr. Graham, Mr. Curry, Mr. Lazenby and Mr. Newsom think that an ordinary trough about nine feet long across steel partitions dividing both box stalls similar to an ordinary wooden horse trough. You will note that plan shows door into stalls in centre of stalls. These doors are placed next cross partitions, which is as Beatty's standard fixtures call for. We are allowing three feet for door to swing in with a nine foot trough leading back to North and South. If there is a difference in troughs Concrete Mangers could be deducted from wooden mangers.

Re Cow Barn. Plan shows front elevation of hay loft doors. We have no rear elevation of these gables. These men desire the two lower doors on one end and dispense with the hay loft door above as they only use one door for loading hay into loft, and peak

I will be pleased to know what colours you will be painting sidings of these barns and also what colour for roof.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that an expert from Winnipeg arrived at the new residential school yesterday, to put into operation the filtering and chlorinating plants. Mr Rose, of the Dominion Water Powers Reclamation Branch at Winnipeg has been superintending the installation of these plants, and stated that once the chlorinator was put into operation, it should be kept going. I therefore asked that the putting of these plants into operation be deferred until such time as there was a competent man to take charge of them, as there is no such person at present on the school staff, and the expert agreed to come to Birtle again when required.

I trust the Department will approve of my action in taking the above step, and would recommend that a competent man be engaged without delay, to take charge of the furnaces, heating system, and water system. This man should, I think, be in possession of at least a 3rd class steam engineer's certificate.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a statement of accounts submitted on behalf of Mr. W. H. Dalton, of Neepawa, Manitoba, covering work done at the Birtle Indian Residential School; also accounts and pay-lists are enclosed, in triplicate.

These accounts are as submitted by Mr. Dalton, except that I have only allowed for him $1.12½ per hour for time spent by him on the work, instead of $1.50 per hour as submitted by himself, and the 10% profit upon his own wages has not been allowed. There is still an outstanding account amounting to approximately $125.00, which will be forwarded to you as soon as received here properly receipted.

I have had some discussion with Mr. Dalton over the rate of pay to be allowed him for the time spent on the work by himself. Mr. Dalton considers he is entitled to $1.50 per hour. The question of any payment to Mr. Dalton for supervision of the work did not arise at the time the contract was given to him. However, I consider that $1.12½ per hour is a fair allowance for Mr. Dalton's time.

I may say that the work was done in a satisfactory manner and that the accounts as submitted to you are considered fair and just, and I would request that a cheque for $182.82, made payable to the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Neepawa, for the account of W. H. Dalton, be forwarded to me as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Acting District Chief Engineer.

December 16, 1930.

Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy

I have given consideration to the attached papers containing the suggestion that the old building of the Birtle Residential School should be left standing and utilized in some way.

When the transfer which is now under way is complete, (the Department of Justice is at present examining titles, etc.) this property will be in the Crown. It is our intention to raise this old building and clear the ground. The suggestion as to how it might be used is so vague that it is difficult to deal with that aspect of the case, but I would be opposed on general grounds to maintaining this building, and it would hardly be in the interests of our work to have another institution in such close proximity to the school. Then the question arises,- why should the Dominion Government make a present of this building to the town of Birtle? It would be certainly very unusual. I am afraid the local people have not given this matter very careful consideration.

Dear Sir:

Re: Birtle Indian School

The finishing work at the School is being pushed with the expectation that all items of work under our contract will be completed in two or at the most three weeks from this date.

During the last month there has been some conversations at Birtle which I think have reached our foreman from Mr. Henderson that in all probability there will be a number of interior fittings, etc., to be made. We would be very glad to be favored with the order for this work. It can be done now most economically, and in view of the number of men we have on the job can be completed very rapidly.

I saw Mr. Curry yesterday, and was told by him how anxious they are to get out of the old building owing to its dilapidated state. We should be very pleased to co-operate to this end.

Mr. Curry, and some ladies who were looking over the School, mentioned very insistently to us the desirability of having the concrete floors painted. The floors are very good, but there is no question about there being a certain amount of dusting if they are not painted. May we suggest that the floors and the cement base be given one or two coats of suitable paint?

The finish of the corridor floors is ¼" below that in the room, as a preparation for linoleum. May we have the order?

The platform of the Chapel is at present only 7" above the main floor of the room. I was asked about the possibility of raising the platform in the Chapel by about a foot, and was requested to take this point up with you. Provision for entry into the rooms at the side of the platform can be made by either alternates.
as shown on enclosed sketch.

We would be very glad to receive an order for any or all of the above mentioned items. We will give them careful and economical supervision and carry out the work for cost plus 10%. We would especially appreciate receiving an order for all the farther incidentals required around the building. We have, as you must be aware a very close price, and if this work is ordered it can be done without increasing the heating cost prior to it being taken over by the Government.

All other work around the building, such as sewer, water works, etc., which are usually made additions to the work of the General Contractor, have been awarded to outside parties, and we would, therefore, have a double appreciation in being allowed to finish off all other items of work.

Trusting we may receive a favorable reply, we are,

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED

The new school under way, is rapidly nearing completion, from my best observation, I believe the Contractors, Claydon Construction Co., will finish their contract within three weeks. But there remains much work to be done, in the way of extras, or furnishings, such as built-in cupboards, wardrobes, pupils dining room tables, benches, shelving and a great deal of such equipment. In my mind this work should be under way right now. This extra work might be done while the building is in the contractors hands. As soon as the Contractors finish we will have to take the building and keep it heated, while this extra work is being done. Where extra work is put under way now it will be finished about the time the Contractors finish what is required of them. If this extra work is let to the Claydon Construction Co., all they will require is a few extra carpenters.

Working in conjunction with what is now employed. I am very satisfied with the work the Contractors are doing, they appear to select good men for each part of the work. Also the material used appears good dry first class quality. Most certainly that is the necessary material for Cupboards, wardrobes, tables, benches and even shelving, otherwise after drying out it shrinks, twists and looks unsightly. I have observed that when work is done with lumber out of the local lumber yards it dries out afterward. Their lumber may be just as good, and at some time has passed through the dry kill. But after months in the open sheds expands with moisture from the air, later contracting when exposed to heat.

Dear Sir:

Re Cow Barn Ventilation

Ventilation throughout this barn has been carried out as per plan and sections. I wish to draw your attention to the fact that present ventilation in cow barn is not proving satisfactory. Cow barn is fully occupied with cattle and has been sweating for the last three weeks and ceiling is wringing wet throughout and doors are swollen. I feel that a change in ventilation is necessary. I think if the metal ducts passing along on the under side of floor between joists has a hole cut on both outside walls and a louver put in on outside wall at floor level would give more satisfactory results. Unclosed ventilation going up rafters do not seem to act properly. I think a louver on outside of frame
at ceiling level would act better or boxes two feet square carried straight up through hay loft. These boxes would require to be about five feet at each side of centre of barn to allow for hay carrier. This would mean that these ducts should be carried straight across and louvers at each side. The metal boxes only go half way across but balance could be done with V-Joint ceiling at bottom of joist to close place up.

Principal Curry is very much disappointed in this ventilation for this barn. I awaited three weeks to see how this ventilation would act and would be pleased to have your reply to same.

Your obedient servant,

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.

Sir:

I beg to forward herewith in duplicate my report and diary for the month of December, 1930, as follows:

The new Residential school now in course of erection at Birtle is well on towards completion. The plastering is completed, and the interior finishers are at work. On instructions from the Department, I spent some time at the school compiling a detailed list of the furnishings that will be required. Mr. Rose, of the Dominion Water Powers Reclamation Branch at Winnipeg was at the school in connection with the installation of the water system. The system was tested throughout and all leaks and other defects were remedied. The Chlorinating plant, however, is not yet in operation, as it was thought advisable to leave this until some person had been employed to take proper charge of the work. The two barns are completed, and the cow barn is in use.
